titleStmt.title: THE Tragedy of Othello,The Moore of Venice. As it hath beene diverse times acted at the Globe, and at the Black-Friers, by his Maiesties Seruants.

respStmt.name: Tanmay Shah

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Character descriptions: Iago, Othello's ancient Roderigo, A Venetian gentleman Brabantio, A senator of Venice Othello, A noble Moor in the service of the Ventian state Cassio, Othello's lieutenant First Officer Duke Of Venice First Senator, A senator of Venice Second Senator, A senator of Venice Sailor Messenger Desdemona, Daughter to Brabantio and wife to Othello Montanio, Othello's predecessor in the government of Cyprus First Gentleman Second Gentleman Third Gentleman Emilia, Wife to Iago Clown, Servant to Othello First Musician Bianca, Mistress to Cassio Lodouico, Kinsman to Brabantio Gratiano, Brother to Brabantio All Voice off

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.p:
The Stationer to the Reader.
TO set forth a book without an Epistle,
were like to the old English proverb, A
blue coat without a badge,the Author
being dead, I thought good to take
that piece of work upon me: To commend
it, I will not, for that which is good, I hope every
man will commend, without entreaty: and I am the bolder,
because the Authors name is sufficient to vent his
work. Thus leaving every one to the liberty of judgment:
I have ventered to print this Play, and leave it
to the general censure.
Yours,
Thomas Walkley.

div1.head: The Tragedy of Othello the Moore of Venice.

sp.speaker: Roderigo.
sp.l: Tush, never tell me, I take it much unkindly
That you Iago, who has had my purse,
As if the strings were thine, shouldst know of this.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: 'sblood, but you will not hear me,
If ever I did dream of such a matter, abhor me.

sp.speaker: Roderigo.
sp.l: Thou toldest me, thou didst hold him in thy hate.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Despise me if I do not: three great ones of the City
In personal suite to make me his Lieutenant,
Oft capped to him, and by the faith of man,
I know my price, I am worth no worse a place.
But he, as loving his own pride and purposes,
Evades them, with a bombast circumstance,
Horribly stuffed with Epithets of war:
And in conclusion,
Non-suits my mediators: for certes, says he,
I have already chosen my officer, and what was he?
Forsooth, a great Arithmetician,
One Michael Cassio, a Florentine,
A fellow almost damned in a fair wife,
That never set a squadron in the field,
Nor the division of a Battle knows,
More than a Spinster, unless the bookish Theorique,
Wherein the toga'd Consuls can propose
As masterly as he: mere prattle without practise,
Is all his soldiership: but he sir had the election,
And I, of whom his eyes had seen the proof,
At Rhodes, at Cipres, and on other grounds,
Christian and Heathen, must be led, and calmed,
By Debtor and Creditor, this Counter-caster:
: He in good time, must his Lieutenant be,
And I, God bless the mark, his Worship's Ancient.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: By heaven I rather would have been his hangman.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: But there is no remedy,
It is the curse of service,
Preferment goes by letter and affection,
Not by the old gradation, where each second
Stood heir to the first:
Now sir be judge yourself,
Whether I, in any just term am assigned
to love the Moore.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I would not follow him then.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: O sir, content you.
I follow him to serve my turn upon him,
We cannot be all masters, nor all masters
Cannot be truly followed, you shall mark .
Many a duteous and knee-crooking knave,
That doting on his own obsequious bondage,
Wears out his time much like his masters Ass,
For naught but provender, and when he is old cashiered,
Whip me such honest knaues:
Others there are, who trimmed in forms,
And visages of duty, keep yet their hearts,
Attending on themselves, and throwing
But shows of service on their Lords,
Do well thrive by them,
And when they have lined their coats,
Do themselves homage,
Those fellows have some soul,
And such a one do I profess myself, ---- for sir,
It is as sure as you are Roderigo,
Were I the Moore, I would not be Iago:
In following him, I follow but myself.
Heaven is my judge, not I,
For love and duty, but seeming so,
For my peculiar end.
For when my outward action does demonstrate
The native act, and figure of my heart,
In complement extern, it is not long after,
But I will wear my heart upon my sleeve,
For Doves to peck at,
I am not what I am.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What a full fortune does the thick-lips owe,
If he can carry it thus?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Call up her father,
Rouse him, make after him, poison his delight,
Proclaim him in the street, incense her Kinsmen,
And though he in a fertile climate dwell,
Plague him with flies: though that his joy be joy,
Yet throw such changes of vexation out,
As it may lose some colour.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Here is her father's house, I will call aloud.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Do with like timorous accent, and dire yell,
As when by night and negligence, the fire
Is spied in populous Cities.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What ho, Brabantio; Seignior Brabantio, ho,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Awake, what ho, Brabantio,
Thieves, thieves, thieves:
Look to your house, you Daughter, and your bags.
Thieves, thieves.

sp.speaker: Brab.
sp.l: What is the reason of this terrible summons?
What is the matter there?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Seignior, is all your family within?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Are all door locked?

sp.speaker: Brab.
sp.l: Why, wherefore ask you this?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Zounds sir you are robbed, for shame put on your gown,
Your heart is burst, you have lost half your soul;
Even now, very now, an old black Ram
Is tupping your white Ewe; arise, arise,
Awake the snorting Citizens with the Bell,
Or else the Devil will make a Grandsire of you, arise I say.

sp.speaker: Brab.
sp.l: What, have you lost your wits?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Most reverend Seignior, do you know my voice?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Not I, what are you?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: My name is Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Brab.
sp.l: The worse welcome,
I have charged thee, not to haunt about my doors,
In honest plainness, thou hast heard me say
My daughter is not for thee, and now in madness,
Being full of supper, and distempering draughts,
Upon malicious bravery, dost thou come
To start my quiet?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sir, sir, sir.

sp.speaker: Brab.
sp.l: But thou must needs be sure
My spirit and my place have them in power,
To make this bitter to thee.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Patience good sir.

sp.speaker: Brab.
sp.l: What, tellest thou me of robbing? this is Venice,
My house is not a grange.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Most grave Brabantio,
In simple and pure soul I come to you.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Zouns Sir, you are one of those, that will not serve God, if
the Devil bid you. Because we come to do you service, you think
we are Ruffians, you will have your daughter covered with a Barbary
horse; you will have your Nephews neigh to you; you will have Coursers
for Cousins, and Jennets for Germans.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What profane wretch art thou?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
I am one sir, that come to tell you, your daughter, and the
Moore, are now making the Beast with two backs.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Thou art a villain .

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: You are a Senator.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: This thou shalt answer, I know thee Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sir, I will answer anything: But I beseech you,
If she be in her chamber, or your house,
Let loose on me the Justice of the state,
For this delusion.

sp.speaker: Brab.
sp.l: Strike on the tinder, Ho:
Give me a taper, call up all my people:
This accident is not unlike my dream,
Belief of it oppresses me already:
Light I say, light.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Farewell, for I must leave you,
It seems not meet, nor wholesome to my pate,
To be produced, as if I stay I shall
Against the Moore, for I do know the state,
However this may gall him with some check,
Cannot with safety cast him, for he is embarked,
With such loud reason, to the Cipres wars,
Which even now stands in act, that for their souls,
Another of his fathom, they have not
To lead their business, in which regard,
Though I do hate him, as I do hell's pains,
Yet for necessity of present life,
I must show out a flag, and sign of love,
Which is indeed but sign, that you shall surely
Find him: lead to the Sagittar, the raised search,
And there will I be with him. So farewell.

div2.stage: Enter Barbantio in his night gowne, and seruants with Torches.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It is too true an evil, gone she is,
And what is to come, of my despised time,
Is naught but bitterness now Roderigo,
Where didst thou see her; O unhappy girl,
With the Moore sayst thou? who would be a father?
How didst thou know it was she? O thou deceivest me
Past thought: what said she to you? get more tapers,
Raise all my kindred, are they married think you?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Truly I think they are.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O heaven, how got she out? O treason of the blood;
Fathers from hence, trust not your Daughters' minds,
By what you see them act, is there not charms,
By which the property of youth and manhood
May be abused? have you not read Roderigo,
Of some such thing.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I have sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Call up my brother: O that you had had her,
Some one way, some another; do you know
Where we may apprehend her, and the Moore?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I think I can discover him, if you please
To get good guard, and go along with me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Pray lead me on, at every house I will call,
I may command at most: get weapons ho,
And raise some special Officers of night:
On good Roderigo, I will deserve your pains.

div2.stage: Enter Othello, Iago, and attendants with Torches.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Though in the trade of war, I have slain men,
Yet do I hold it very stuffed of Conscience.
To do no contrived murther; I lack iniquity
Sometimes to do me service: nine or ten times,
I had thought to have jerked him here,
Under the ribs.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is better as it is.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Nay, but he prated,
And spoke such scurvy, and provoking terms
Against your Honour, that with the little godliness I have,
I did full hard forbear him: but I pray sir,
Are you fast married? For be sure of this,
That the Magnifico is much beloved,
And hath in his effect, a voice potential,
As double as the Duke's, he will divorce you,
Or put upon you what restraint, and grievance,
That law with all his might to enforce it on,
Will give him cable.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Let him do his spite,
My services which I have done the Seigniorie,
Shall out-tongue his complaints, it is yet to know,
That boasting is an honour,
I shall provulgate, I fetch my life and being,
From men of royal height, and my demerits,
May speak unbonneted to as proud a fortune
As this that I have reached; for know Iago,
But that I love the gentle Desdemona,
I would not, my unhoused free condition,
Put into circumscription and confine
For the seas worth,
But look what lights come yonder.

div2.stage: Enter Cassio with lights, Officers, and torches.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: These are the raised Father and his friends,
You were best go in:

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Not I, I must be found,
My parts, my Title, and my perfect soul,
Shall manifest me rightly: it is they.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Ianus I think no.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The servants of the Duke, and my Lieutenant,
The goodness of the night upon your friends,
What is the news.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Something from Cipres, as I may divine,
It is a business of some heat, the Galleys
Have sent a dozen frequent messengers
This very night, at one another's heels:
And many of the Consuls raised, and met,
Are at the Dukes already: you have been hotly called for,
When being not at your lodging to be found,
The Senate sent above three several quests
To search you out.

sp.speaker: Otht
sp.l: It is well I am found by you,
I will spend a word here in the house, and go with you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Ancient, what makes he here?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Faith he tonight, hath boarded a land Carrack:
If it prove lawful prize, he is made forever.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I do not understand.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: He is married,

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: To who?

div2.stage: Enters Brabantio, Roderigo, and others with lights and weapons.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Marry to.---- Come Captain, will you go?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Ha, with who?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Here comes another troupe to seek for you.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: It is Brabantio, General be advised,
He comes to bad intent.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Holla, stand there.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Seignior, it is the Moore.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Down with him thief.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: You Roderigo, Come sir, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Keep up your bright swords, for the dew will rust them,
Good Seignior you shall more command with years
Than with your weapons.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O thou foul thief, where hast thou stowed my daughter?
Damned as thou art, thou hast inchanted her,
For I will refer me to all thing of sense,
Whether a maid so tender, fair, and happy,
So opposite to marriage, that she shunned
The wealthy curled darlings of our Nation,
Would ever have (to incur a general mock)
Run from her guardage to the sooty bosom
Of such a thing as thou? to fear, not to delight,
Such an abuser of the world, a practiser
Of Arts inhibited, and out of warrant?
Lay hold upon him, if he do resist,
Subdue him at his peril.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Hold your hands:
Both you of my inclining and the rest,
Were it my cue to fight, I should have known it,
Without a prompter, where will you that I go,
And answer this your charge?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: To prison till fit time
Of Law, and course of direct Session,
Call thee to answer.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.l: It is true most worthy Seignior,
The Duke is in Council, and your noble self,
I am sure is sent for.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How? the Duke in Council?
In this time of the night? bring him away,
Mine is not an idle cause, the Duke himself,
Or any of my Brothers of the State,
Cannot but feel this wrong, as it were their own.
For if such actions, may have passage free,
Bondslaves, and Pagans, shall our Statesmen be.

div2.stage: Enter Duke and Senators, set at a Table with lights and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: There is no Composition in these news,
That gives them credit.

sp.speaker: 1 Sena.
sp.l: Indeed they are disproportioned,
My letters say, a hundred and seven Galleys.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And mine a hundred and forty.

sp.speaker: 2 Sena.
sp.l: And mine two hundred:
But though they jump not on a just account,
As in these cases, where they aimed reports,
It is oft with difference, yet do they all confirm
A Turkish fleete, and bearing up to Cipresse.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nay, it is possible enough to judgment:
I do not so secure me to the error,
But the main Articles I do approve
In fearful sense.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: What, ho! what, ho! what, ho!

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: A messenger from the Galley.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now, the business?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: The Turkish preparation makes for Rhodes,
So was I bid report here, to the state.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How say you by this change?

sp.speaker: 1 Sena.
sp.l: This cannot be by no assay of reason ---
It is a Pageant,
To keep us in false gaze: when we consider
The importancy of Cypresse to the Turk:
And let ourselves again, but understand,
That as it more concerns the Turk than Rhodes,
So may he with more facile question bear it.

sp.speaker: Dn.
sp.l: And in all confidence, he is not for Rhodes.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.l: Here is more news.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: The Ottamites, reverend and gracious,
Steering with due course, toward the Isle of Rhodes,
Have there enjointed with an after fleete
Of thirty sail, and now they do restrain
Their backward course, bearing with frank appearance
Their purposes towards Cypresse: Seignior Montano,
Your trusty and most valiant servitor,
With his free duty recommends you thus,
And prays you to believe him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It is certain then for Cypresse,
Marcus Luccicos is not here in Town.

sp.speaker: 1 Sena.
sp.l: He is now in Florence.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Write from us, wish him post, post haste dispatch.

sp.speaker: 1 Sena.
sp.l: Here comes Brabantio and the valiant Moore.

div2.stage: Enter Brabantio, Othello, Roderigo, Iago, Cassio, Desdemona, and Officers.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Valiant Othello, we must straight employ you,
Against the general enemy Ottaman;
I did not see you, welcome gentle Seignior,
We lack your counsel, and your help tonight,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So did I yours, good your Grace pardon me,
Neither my place, nor aught I heard of business
Hath raised me from my bed, nor doth the general care
Take any hold of me, for my particular griefs,
Is of so floodgate and overbearing nature,
That it engluts, and swallows other sorrows,
And it is still itself.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My daughter, O my daughter.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I to me:
She is abused, stolen from me and corrupted,
By spells and medicines, bought of mountebanks,
For nature so preposterously to err,
Sans witchcraft could not.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Whoever he be, that in this foul proceeding
Hath thus beguiled your daughter of herself,
And you of her, the bloody book of Law,
You shall yourself, read in the bitter letter,
After its own sense, though our proper son
Stood in your action.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Humbly I thank your Grace;
Here is the man, this Moore, whom now it seems
Your special mandate, for the State affairs
Hath hither brought.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We are very sorry for .

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What in your own part can you say to this?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Nothing, but this is so.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Most potent, grave, and reverend Seigniors,
My very noble and approved good masters:
That I have taken away this old man's daughter,
It is most true: true, I have married her,
The very head and front of my offending,
Hath this extent no more. Rude am I in my speech,
And little blessed with the set phrase of peace,
For since these arms of mine had seven years' pith,
Till now some nine Moons wasted, they have used
Their dearest action in the tented field,
And little of this great world can I speak,
More than pertains to feat of broil, and battle,
And therefore little shall I grace my cause,
In speaking for myself; yet by your gracious patience,
I will a round unvarnished tale deliver,
Of my whole course of love, what drugs, what charms,
What conjuration, and what mighty Magic,
(For such proceedings am I charged withal:)
I won his daughter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A maiden never bold of spirit,
So still and quiet, that her motion
Blushed at herself: and she in spite of nature,
Of years, of Country, credit, everything,
To fall in love with what she feared to look on?
It is a judgment maimed, and most imperfect,
That will confess perfection, so would err
Against all rules of Nature, and must be driven,
To find out practises of cunning hell,
Why this should be, I therefore vouch again,
That with some mixtures powerful over the blood,
Or with some dram conjured to this effect,
He wrought upon her.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: To youth this is no proof,
Without more certain and more overt test,
These are thin habits, and poor likelihoods,
Of modern seemings, you prefer against him.

sp.speaker: 1 Sena.
sp.l: But Othello speak,
Did you by indirect and forced courses,
Subdue and poison this young maid's affections?
Or came it by request, and such fair question,
As soul to soul affordeth?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I do beseech you,
Send for the Lady to the Sagittar,
And let her speak of me before her father;
If you do find me foul in her report,
Not only take away, but let your sentence
Even fall upon my life.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Fetch Desdemona hither.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Ancient conduct them, you best know the place:

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: And till she come, as faithful as to heaven,
So justly to your grave ears I will present,
How I did thrive in this fair Lady's love,
And she in mine.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Say it Othello.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Her Father loved me, oft invited me,
Still questioned me the story of my life,
From year to year; the battles, sieges, fortunes
That I have past:
I ran it through, even from my boyish days,
To the very moment that he bade me tell it.
Wherein I spake of most disastrous chances,
Of moving accident of flood and field;
Of hairbreadth scapes in the imminent deadly breach;
Of being taken by the insolent foe:
And sold to slavery, and my redemption thence,
And with it all my travel's History;
Wherein of Antres vast, and Deserts idle,
Rough quarries, rocks and hills, whose heads touch heaven,
It was my hint to speak, such was the process:
And of the Cannibals, that each other eat;
The Anthropophagie, and men whose heads
Do grow beneath their shoulders: this to hear,
Would Desdemona seriously incline;
But still the house affairs would draw her thence,
And ever as she could with haste dispatch,
She would come again, and with a greedy ear
Devour up my discourse; which I observing,
Took once a pliant hour, and found good means
To draw from her a prayer of earnest heart,
That I would all my pilgrimage dilate,
Whereof by parcel she had something heard,
But not intentively, I did consent,
And often did beguile her of her tears,
When I did speak of some distressed stroke
That my youth suffered: my story being done;
She gave me for my pains a world of sighs;
She swore Ifaith it was strange, it was passing strange;
It was pitiful, it was wondrous pitiful;
She wished she had not heard it, yet she wished
That Heaven had made her such a man: she thanked me,
And bad me, if I had a friend that loved her,
I should but teach him how to tell my story,
And that would woo her. Upon this heat I spake:
She loved me for the dangers I had past.
And I loved her that she did pity them.
This only is the witchcraft I have used:
Here comes the Lady,
Let her witness it.

div2.stage: Enter Desdemona, Iago, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I think this tale would win my daughter too, ----
Good Brabantio, take up this mangled matter at the best,
Men do their broken weapons rather use,
Than their bare hands.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I pray you hear her speak.
If she confess that she was half the wooer,
Destruction lite on me, if my bad blame
Light on the man. Come hither gentle mistress:
Do you perceive in all this noble company,
Where most you owe obedience?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: My noble father,
I do perceive here a divided duty:
To you I am bound for life and education;
My life and education both do learn me
How to respect you, you are Lord of all my duty,
I am hitherto your daughter, But here is my husband:
And so much duty as my mother showed
To you, preferring you before her father,
So much I challenge, that I may profess,
Due to the Moore my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: God bu'y, I have done:
Please it your Grace, on to the State affairs;
I had rather to adopt a child than get it;
Come hither Moore:
I here do give thee that with all my heart
I would keep from thee: for your sake Jewel,
I am glad at soul. I have no other child,
For thy escape would teach me tyranny,
To hang clogs on them, I have done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Let me speak like yourself, and lay a sentence
Which as a grise or step may help these lovers
Into your favour.
When remedies are past, the griefs are ended,
By seeing the worst, which late on hopes depended,
To mourn a mischief that is past and gone,
Is the next way to draw more mischief on
What cannot be preserved when fortune takes,
Patience her injury a mockery makes.
The robbed that smiles, steals something from the thief,
He robs himself, that spends a bootless grief.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So let the Turk, of Cypres us beguile,
We lose it not so long as we can smile;
He bears the sentence well that nothing bears,
But the free comfort, which from thence he hears:
But he bears both the sentence and the sorrow,
That to pay grief, must of poor patience borrow.
These sentences to sugar, or to gall,
Being strong on both sides, are equivocal:
But words are words, I never yet did hear,
That the bruised heart was pierced through the ear:
Beseech you now, to the affairs of the state.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p:
The Turk with most mighty preparation makes for Cipres:
Othello, the fortitude of the place, is best known to you, and though we
have there a substitute of most allowed sufficiency, yet opinion, a sovereign
mistress of effects, throws a more safer voice on you; you
must therefore be content to slubber the gloss of your new fortunes,
with this more stubborn and boisterous expedition.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The tyrant custom most great Senators,
Hath made the flinty and steel Couch of war,
My thrice driven bed of down: I do agnize
A natural and prompt alacrity,
I find in hardness, and would undertake
This present wars against the Ottamites,
Most humbly therefore, bending to your State,
I crave fit disposition for my wife,
Due reverence of place and exhibition,
Which such accommodation? and besort
As levels with her breeding.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: If you please, be it at her fathers.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will not have it so.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Nor I, I would not there reside,
To put my father in impatient thoughts,
By being in his eye: most gracious Duke,
To my unfolding lend a gracious ear,
And let me find a charter in your voice,
And if my simpleness. ----

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What would you ----speake.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: That I did love the Moore, to live with him,
My downright violence, and scorn of Fortunes,
May trumpet to the world: my hearts subdued,
Even to the utmost pleasure of my Lord:
I saw Othello's visage in his mind,
And to his Honours, and his valiant parts
Did I my soul and fortunes consecrate:
So that dear Lords, if I be left behind,
A Moth of peace, and he go to the war,
The rites for which I love him, are bereft me,
And I a heavy interim shall support,
By his dear absence, let me go with him.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Your voices Lords: beseech you let her will,
Have a free way, I therefore beg it not
To please the palate of my appetite,
Nor to comply with heat, the young affects
In my defunct, and proper satisfaction,
But to be free and bounteous of her mind,
And heaven defend your good souls that you think
I will your serious and good business scant,
For she is with me; --- no, when light-winged toys,
And feathered Cupid foils with wanton dullness,
My speculative and active instruments,
That my disports, corrupt and taint my business,
Let housewives make a skillet of my Helm,
And all indign and base adversities,
Make head against my reputation.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Be it, as you shall privately determine,
Either for stay or going, the affairs cry haste,
And speed must answer, you must hence tonight,

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Tonight my Lord?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This night.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: At ten in the morning here we will meet again.
Othello, leave some officer behind,
And he shall our Commission bring to you,
With such things else of quality or respect,
As doth concern you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Please your Grace, my Ancient,
A man he is of honesty and trust,
To his conveyance I assign my wife,
With what else needful your good Grace shall think,
To be sent after me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Let it be so:
Good night to everyone,
and noble Seignior,
If vertue no delighted beauty lack,
Your son-in-law is far more fair than black.

sp.speaker: 1 Sena.
sp.l: Adieu brave Moore, use Desdemona well.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Look to her Moore, have a quick eye to see,
She has deceived her father, may do thee.

div2.stage: Exeunt DUKE OF VENICE, Senators, Officers

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: My life upon her faith: honest Iago,
My Desdemona must I leave to thee,
I prithee let thy wife attend on her,
And bring her after in the best advantage;
Come Desdemona, I have but an hour
Of love, of worldly matters, and direction,
To spend with thee, we must obey the time.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Iago.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: What sayst thou noble heart?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: What will I do thinkest thou?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Why go to bed and sleep.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I will incontinently drown myself.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Well, if thou dost, I shall never love thee after it,
Why, thou silly Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
It is silliness to live, when to live is a torment, and then we
have a prescription, to dye when death is our Physician.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
I have looked upon the world for four times seven years,
and since I could distinguish between a benefit, and an injury, I never
found a man that knew how to love himself: ere I would say
I would drown myself, for the love of a Ginny Hen, I would
change my humanity with a Baboon.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
What should I do? I confess it is my shame to be so fond,
but it is not in my vertue to amend it.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Vertue? a fig, it is in ourselves, that we are thus, or thus,
our bodies are gardens, to the which our wills are Gardeners, so that
if we will plant Nettles, or sow Lettuce, set Isop, and weed up Time;
supply it with one gender of herbs, or distract it with many; either
to have it sterile with Idleness, or manured with Industry, why
the power, and corrigible Authority of this, lies in our wills. If the
balance of our lives had not one scale of reason, to poise another of
sensuality; the blood and baseness of our natures, would conduct
us to most preposterous conclusions. But we have reason to cool
our raging motions, our carnal stings, our unbitted lusts; whereof
I take this, that you call love to be a sect, or scion.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
It is merely a lust of the blood, and a permission of the will:
Come, be a man; drown thyself? drown Cats and blind Puppies:
I profess me thy friend, and I confess me knit to thy deserving,
with cables of perdurable toughness; I could never better
steed thee than now. Put money in thy purse; follow these wars,
defeat thy favour with an usurped beard; I say, put money in thy
purse. It cannot be, that Desdemona should long continue her love
unto the Moore, --- put money in thy purse, -- nor he to her; it was
a violent commencement, and thou shalt see an answerable sequestration:
put but money in thy purse. ---These Moors are changeable
in their wills: --- fill thy purse with money. The food that to
him now, is as luscious as Locusts, shall be to him shortly as acerbic
as the Colloquintida. When she is sated with his body, she will
find the error of her choice; she must have change, she must.
Therefore put money in thy purse: if thou wilt needs damn
thyself, do it a more delicate way than drowning; make all
the money thou canst. If sanctimony, and a frail vow, betwixt an
erring Barbarian, and a super subtle Venetian, be not too hard for my
wits, and all the tribe of hell, thou shalt enjoy her; therefore make
money, --- a pox a-drowning, it is clean out of the way: seek thou
rather to be hanged in compassing thy joy, than to be drowned, and
go without her.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Wilt thou be fast to my hopes?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Thou art sure of me ---goe, make money --- I have told
thee often, and I tell thee again, and again, I hate the Moore, my
cause is hearted, thine has no less reason, let us be communicative in
our revenge against him: If thou canst cuckold him, thou dost thyself
a pleasure, and me a sport. There are many events in the womb
of Time, which will be delivered. Traverse, go, provide thy money,
we will have more of this tomorrow, Adieu.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Where shall we meet in the morning.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: At my lodging.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I will be with thee betimes.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Go to, farewell: ---do you hear Roderigo?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: what say you?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: No more of drowning, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I am changed.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Go to, farewell, put money enough in your purse:
Thus do I ever make my fool my purse:
For I mine own gained knowledge should profane,
If I would time expend with such a snipe,
But for my sport and profit: I hate the Moore,
And it is thought abroad, that twixt my sheets
He has done my office; I know not, if it be true ---
Yet I, for mere suspicion in that kind,
Will do, as if for surety: he holds me well,
The better shall my purpose work on him.
Cassio is a proper man, let me see now,
To get this place, and to make up my will,
A double knavery --- how, how, --- let me see,
After some time, to abuse Othello's ear,
That he is too familiar with his wife:
He has a person and a smooth dispose,
To be suspected, framed to make women false:
The Moore a free and open nature too,
That thinks men honest, that but seems to be so:
And will as tenderly be led by the nose --- as Asses are:
I have it, it is engendered: Hell and night
Must bring this monstrous birth to the worlds light.

div2.stage: Enter Montanio, Gouernor of Cypres, with two other Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Montanio.
sp.l: What from the Cape can you discern at Sea?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nothing at all, it is a high wrought flood,
I cannot twixt the haven and the main
Descry a sail.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Methinks the wind does speak aloud at land,
A fuller blast never shook our Battlements:
If it have ruffianed so upon the sea.
What ribs of Oak, when the huge mountain melt,
Can hold the mortise, --- What shall we hear of this?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A segregation of the Turkish Fleete:
For do but stand upon the banning shore,
The chiding billow seems to pelt the clouds,
The wind shaked surge, with high and monstrous main,
Seems to cast water, on the burning Bear,
And quench the guards of the ever fixed pole,
I never did, like molestation view,
On the inchafed flood.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: If that the Turkish Fleete
Be not ensheltered, and embayed, they are drowned,
It is impossible they bear it out.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: News Lords, your wars are done:
The desperate Tempest hath so banged the
Turk,
That their designment halts: Another ship of Venice hath seen
A grievous wrack and sufferance
On most part of the Fleete.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: How, is this true?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The ship is here put in:
A Veronessa, Michael Cassio,
Lieutenant to the warlike Moore Othello,
Is come ashore: the Moore himself at Sea,
And is in full Commission here for Cypres,

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am glad on it, it is a worthy Governor.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But this same Cassio, though he speak of comfort,
Touching the Turkish loss, yet he looks sadly,
And prays the Moore be safe, for they were parted,
With foul and violent Tempest.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Pray Heaven he be:
For I have served him, and the man commands
Like a full Soldier:
Let us to the sea side, ho,
As well to see the vessel that is come in,
As to throw out our eyes for brave Othello.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come, let us do so,
For every minute is expectancy
Of more arrivance,

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Thanks to the valiant of this worthy Isle,
That so approve the Moore, and let the heavens
Give him defence against their Elements,
For I have lost him on a dangerous sea.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Is he well shipped?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: His Bark is stoutly timbered, and his Pilot
Of very expert and approved allowance,
Therefore my hope is not surfeited to death,
Stand in bold cure.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: A sail, a sail, a sail.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: What noise?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: The Town is empty, on the brow of the sea,
stand ranks of people, and they cry a sail.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: My hopes do shape him for the government.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: They do discharge the shot of courtesy,
Our friend at least.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I pray you sir go forth,
And give us truth, who it is that is arrived.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But good Lieutenant, is your General wived?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Most fortunately, he hath achieved a maid,
That paragons description, and wild fame:
One that excels the blazoning pens,
And in the essential vesture of creation,
Does bear all excellency: --- now, who has put in?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It is one Iago, ancient to the General,
He has had most favourable and happy speed,
Tempests themselves, by seas, and howling winds,
The guttered rocks, and congregated sands,
Traitors ensteeped; to clog the guiltless Keel,
As having sense of beauty, do omit
Their common natures, letting go safely by
The divine Desdemona.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What is she?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: She that I spoke of, our great Captain's Captain,
Left in the conduct of the bold Iago.
Whose footing here anticipates our thoughts
A sennight's speed --- great Jove Othello guard,
And swell his sail with thine own powerful breath,
That he may bless this Bay with his tall ship,
And swiftly come to Desdemona's arms.
Give renewed fire,
To our extincted spirits.
And bring all Cypresse comfort,

div2.stage: Enter Desdemona, Iago, Emillia, and Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: ---O behold
The riches of the ship is come ashore.
Ye men of Cypres, let her have your knees:
Hail to thee Lady: and the grace of heaven,
Before, behind thee, and on every hand,
Inhale thee round.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I thank you valiant Cassio:
What tidings can you tell me of my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: He is not yet arrived, nor know I aught,
But that he is well, and will be shortly here.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: O but I fear: ---how lost you company?

sp.p: A sail, a sail

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The great contention of the sea and skies
Parted our fellowship: but hark, A sail.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: They give their greeting to the Citadel,
This likewise is a friend.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: So speaks this voice:
Good Ancient, you are welcome,

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: welcome Mistress,
Let it not gall your patience, good Iago,
That I extend my manners, it is my breeding,
That gives me this bold show of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: For would she give you so much of her lips,
As of her tongue, she has bestowed on me,
You would have enough.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Alas! she has no speech.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I know too much.
I find it, I; for when I have list to sleep,
Marry, before your Ladyship I grant,
She puts her tongue a little in her heart,
And chides with thinking.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You have little cause to say so.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Come on, Come on, you are Pictures out of doors:
Bells in your Parlours: Wildcats in your Kitchens:
Saints in your injuries: Devils being offended:
Players in your housewifery; and housewives in your beds.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: O fie upon thee slanderer.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Nay, it is true, or else I am a Turk,
You rise to play, and go to bed to work.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You shall not write my praise.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: No, let me not.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: What wouldst thou write of me,
If thou shouldst praise me?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: O gentle Lady, do not put me to it ,
For I am nothing, if not Critical.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Come on, assay ---there is one gone to the Harbour?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I Madam.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I am not merry, but I do beguile
The thing I am, by seeming otherwise:
Come, how wouldst thou praise me?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I am about it, but indeed my invention
Comes from my pate, as bird-lime does from freeze,
It plucks out brain and all: but my Muse labours,
And thus she is delivered:
If she be fair and wise, fairness and wit;
The one is for use, the other using it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Well praised: how if she be black and witty?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: If she be black, and thereto have a wit,
She will find a white, that shall her blackness hit.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How if fair and foolish?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: She never yet was foolish, that was fair,
For even her folly helped her, to a hair.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: These are old paradoxes, to make fools laugh in the Alehouse,
sp.l: What miserable praise hast thou for her,
That is foul and foolish?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: There is none so foul, and foolish thereunto,
But does foul pranks, which fair and wise ones do.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p:
O heavy ignorance, that praises the worst best: but what
praise couldst thou bestow on a deserving woman indeed? one,
that in the authority of her merits, did justly put on the vouch of
very malice itself?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: She that was ever fair, and never proud,
Had tongue at will, and yet was never loud,
Never lacked gold, and yet went never gay,
Fled from her wish, and yet said, now I may:
She that being angered, her revenge being nigh,
Bad her wrong stay, and her displeasure fly;
She that in wisdom, never was so frail,
To change the Codshead for the Salmons tail.
She that could think, and never disclose her mind,
She was a wight, if ever such wight were.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: To do what?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: To suckle fools, and chronicle small Beer.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p:
O most lame and impotent conclusion:
Do not learn of him Emillia, though he be thy husband;
How say you Cassio, is he not a most profane and liberal
Counsellor?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: He speaks home Madam, you may relish him
More in the Soldier than in the Scholar.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
He takes her by the palm; aye well said, whisper: as little a
web as this will ensnare as great a Flie as Cassio. Aye smile upon
her, do: I will catch you in your own courtesies: you say true,
it is so indeed. If such tricks as these strip you out of your Lieutenantry,
it had been better you had not kissed your three fingers so oft,
which now again, you are most apt to play the sir in: good, well
kissed, an excellent courtesy; it is so indeed: yet again, your fingers at
your lips? Would they were Clyster-pipes for your sake.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: The Moore, I know his Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: It is truly so.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Let us meet him, and receive him.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Lo, where he comes.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O my fair Warrior.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: My dear Othello.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It gives me wonder great as my content,
To see you here before me: O my soul's joy,
If after every tempest, come such calmness,
May the winds blow, till they have wakened death,
And let the labouring Bark clime hills of seas,
Olympus high, and duck again as low,
As hell is from Heaven: If it were now to dye,
It were now to be most happy, for I fear
My soul hath her content so absolute,
That not another comfort, like to this
Succeeds in unknown Fate,

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: The Heavens forbid,
But that our loves and comforts should increase,
Even as our days do grow.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Amen to that sweet power,
I cannot speak enough of this content,
It stops me here, it is too much of joy:
And this, and this, the greatest discord be,

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That ever our hearts shall make.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: O, you are well tuned now,
But I will set down the pegs, that make this music,
As honest as I am.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Come, let us to the Castle:
News friends, our wars are done, the Turks are drowned:
How do our old acquaintance of the Isle;
Honey, you shall be well desired in Cypres;
I have found great love amongst them: O my sweet,
I prattle out of fashion, and I dote,
In mine own comforts: I prithee good Iago,
Go to the Bay, and disembark my Coffers;
Bring thou the Master to the Citadel;
He is a good one, and his worthiness,
Does challenge much respect: come Desdemona,
Once more well met at Cypres.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Do thou meet me presently at the Harbour: come hither,
If thou beest valiant, as they say, base men being in love, have then
a Nobility in their natures, more than is native to them --- list me,
the Lieutenant tonight watches on the Court of Guard: first I will
tell thee, this Desdemona is directly in love with him.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: With him? why it is not possible.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Lay thy finger thus, and let thy soul be instructed: mark
me, with what violence she first loved the Moore, but for bragging,
and telling her fantastical lies; and will she love him still for prating?
let not the discreet heart think so. Her eye must be fed, and
what delight shall she have to look on the Devil? When the blood
is made dull with the act of sport, there should be again to inflame
it, and give satiety a fresh appetite. Love lines in favour, sympathy
in years, manners and beauties; all which the Moore is defective in:
now for want of these required conveniences, her delicate tenderness
will find itself abused, begin to heave the gorge, disrelish
and abhor the Moore, very nature will instruct her to it, and compel
her to some second choice: now sir, this granted, as it is a most
pregnant and unforced position, who stands so eminently in the degree
of this fortune, as Cassio does? a knave very voluble, no farther
conscionable, than in putting on the mere form of civil and handseeming,
for the better compassing of his salt and hidden affections:
A subtle slippery knave, a finder out of occasions; that has an
eye, can stamp and counterfeit the true advantages never present
themselves. Besides, the knave is handsome, young, and hath all those
requisites in him that folly and green minds look after; a pestilent
complete knave, and the woman has found him already.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I cannot believe that in her, she is full of most blessed condition.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Blessed figs end: the wine she drinks is made of grapes: if
she had been blessed, she would never have loved the Moore. Didst
thou not see her paddle with the palm of his hand?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Yes, but that was but courtesy.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Lechery, by this hand: an Index and prologue to the history
of lust and foul thoughts: they met so near with their lips,
that their breathes embraced together. When these mutualities
so marshall the way, hand at hand, comes the main exercise, the incorporate
conclusion. But sir, be you ruled by me, I have brought
you from Venice: watch you tonight, for your command I will lay it
upon you, Cassio knows you not, I will not be far from you, do you
find some occasion to anger Cassio, either by speaking too loud, or
tainting his discipline, or from what other cause you please; which
the time shall more favourably minister.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Sir he is rash, and very sudden in choler, and haply with his
Truncheon may strike at you; provoke him that he may, for even out
of that will I cause these of Cypres to mutiny, whose qualification
shall come into no true trust again, but by the displanting of Cassio:
So shall you have a shorter journey to your desires by the means I
shall then have to prefer them, and the impediment, most profitably removed,
without which there were no expectation of our prosperity.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I will do this, if I can bring it to any opportunity.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
I warrant thee, meet me by and by at the Citadel; I must
fetch his necessaries ashore. --- Farewell.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: That Cassio loves her, I do well believe it;
That she loves him, it is apt and of great credit;
The Moore howbeit, that I endure him not,
Is of a constant, noble, loving nature;
And I dare think, he will prove to Desdemona,
A most dear husband: now I do love her too,
Not out of absolute lust, though peradventure.
I stand accountant for as great a sin,
But partly led to diet my revenge,
For that I do suspect the lustful Moore,
Hath leaped into my seat, the thought whereof
Doth like a poisonous mineral gnaw my inwards,
And nothing can, nor shall content my soul,
Till I am even with him, wife, for wife:
Or failing so, yet that I put the Moore,
At least, into a Jealousy so strong,
That Judgment cannot cure; which thing to do,
If this poor trash of Venice, whom I crush,
For his quick hunting, stand the putting on,
I will have our Michael Cassio on the hip,
Abuse him to the Moore, in the rank garb,
(For I fear Cassio, with my nightcap too)
Make the Moore thank me, love me, and reward me,
For making him egregiously an Ass,
And practising upon his peace and quiet,
Even to madness: it is here, but yet confused,
Knaveries plain face is never seen, till used.

div2.stage: Enter a Gentleman reading a Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p:
It is Othello's pleasure; our noble and valiant General, that upon
certain tidings now arrived, importing the mere perdition of the
Turkish Fleete; that every man put himself into triumph: Some to
dance, some make bonfires; each man to what sport and Revels
his mind leads him; for besides these beneficial news, it
is the celebration of his Nuptials: So much was his pleasure
should be proclaimed. All Offices are open, and there is full
liberty, from this present hour of five, till the bell hath told
eleven. Heaven bless the Isle of Cypres, and our noble General
Othello.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Good Michael, look you to the guard tonight,
Let us teach ourselves the honourable stop,
Not to out-sport discretion.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Iago hath directed what to do:
But notwithstanding with my personal eye
Will I look to it.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Iago is most honest,
Michael good night, tomorrow with your earliest,
Let me have speech with you, come my dear love,
The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue,
The profits yet to come twixt me and you,
Good night.

div2.stage: Exit Othello and Desdemona. Enter Iago.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Welcome Iago, we must to the watch.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Not this hour Lieutenant, it is not yet ten o'clock: our General
cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemena. who let us
not therefore blame, he hath not yet made wanton the night with
her; and she is sport for Jove.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: She is a most exquisite Lady.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: And I will warrant her full of game.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Indeed she is a most fresh and delicate creature.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
What an eye she has?
Methinks it sounds a parley of provocation.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: An inviting eye, and yet methinks right modest.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: And when she speaks, it is an alarm to love.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: It is indeed perfection.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Well, happiness to their sheets ---come Lieutenant, I
have a stoup of Wine, and here without are a brace of Cypres Gallants,
that would fain have a measure to the health of the black
Othello.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
Not tonight, good Iago; I have very poor and unhappy
brains for drinking: I could well wish courtesy would invent some
other custom of entertainment.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: O they are our friends, ---but one cup: I will drink for you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
I have drunk but one cup tonight, and that was craftily qualified
too, and behold what innovation it makes here: I am unfortunate
in the infirmity, and dare not task my weakness with
any more.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: What man, it is a night of Revels, the Gallants desire it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Here at the door, I pray you call them in.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I will do it , but it dislikes me.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: If I can fasten but one cup upon him,
With that which he hath drunk tonight already,
He will be as full of quarrel and offence,
As my young mistress's dog: ---Now my sick fool Roderigo,
Whom love has turned almost the wrong side outward,
To Desdemona, hath tonight caroused
Potations pottle deep, and he is to watch
Three lads of Cypres, noble swelling spirits,
That hold their honour, in a wary distance,
The very Elements of this warlike Isle,
Have I tonight flustered with flowing cups,
And the watch too: now amongst this flock of drunkards,
I am to put our Cassio in some action,
That may offend the Isle;
But here they come:
If consequence do but approve my dream,
My boat sails freely, both with wind and stream.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Fore God they have given me a rouse already.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Good faith a little one, not past a pint,
As I am a soldier.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Some wine ho:
And let me the Cannikin clink, clink,
And let me the Cannikin clink, clink:
A Soldier is a man, a life is but a span,
Why then let a soldier drink. ---Some wine boys,

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Fore God an excellent song.

sp.speaker: Iag.
Cas.
sp.p: English man so expert in his drinking?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Why he drinks you with facility, your Dane dead drunk:
he sweats not to overthrow your Almaine; he gives your Hollander
a vomit, ere the next pottle can be filled.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: To the health of our General.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I am for it Lieutenant, and I will do you justice.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: O sweet England, ---King Stephen was a worthy peer,
His breeches cost him but a crown,
He held them sixpence all too dear,
With that he called the Taylor lown,
He was a wight of high renown,
And thou art but of low degree,
It is pride that pulls the Country down,
Then take thine owed cloak about thee.
Some wine ho.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Fore God this is a more exquisite song than the other.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Will you hear it again?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
No, for I hold him unworthy of his place, that does those
things: well, God is above all, and there be souls that must be
saved.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: It is true good Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
For mine own part, no offence to the General, nor any man
of quality, I hope to be saved.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: And so do I Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
Aye, but by your leave, not before me; the Lieutenant is to be
saved before the Ancient. Let us have no more of this, let us to our affairs:
God forgive us our sins: Gentlemen, let us look to our business;
Do not think Gentlemen I am drunk, this is my Ancient,
this is my right hand, and this is my left hand: I am not drunk now,
I can stand well enough, and speak well enough.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Excellent well.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Very well then: you must not think, that I am drunk.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: To the platform masters. Come, let us set the watch.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: You see this fellow that is gone before,
He is a Soldier fit to stand by Caesar,
And give direction: and do but see his vice,
It is to his vertue, a just equinox,
The one as long as the other : it is pity of him,
I fear the trust Othello put him in,
On some odd time of his infirmity,
Will shake this Island.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But is he often thus.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: It is evermore the Prologue to his sleep:
He will watch the horologe a double set,
If drink rock not his cradle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: It were well the General were put in mind of it,
Perhaps he sees it not, or his good nature,
Praises the virtues that appears in Cassio,
And look not on his evils: is not this true?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: How now Roderigo,
I pray you after the Lieutenant, go.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: And it is great pity that the noble Moore
Should hazard such a place, as his own second,
With one of an engraft infirmity:
It were an honest action to say so to the Moore.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Nor I, for this fair Island:
I do love Cassio well, and would do much,
To cure him of this evil: but hark, what noise.

div2.stage: Cry within: 'Help! help!' Re-enter CASSIO, driving in RODERIGO

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Zouns, you rogue, you rascal.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What is the matter Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
A knave, teach me my duty: but I will beat the knave into
a wicker bottle.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Beat me?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Dost thou prate rogue?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good Lieutenant; pray sir hold your hand.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Let me go sir, or I will knock you over the mazzard.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come, come, you are drunk.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Drunk?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Away I say, go out and cry a mutiny.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Nay good Lieutenant: godswill Gentlemen,
Help ho, Lieutenant: Sir Montanio, sir,
Help masters, here is a goodly watch indeed,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Who is that that rings the bell? Dibble --- ho,
The Town will rise, godswill Lieutenant, hold,
You will be shamed forever.

div2.stage: Enter Othello, and Gentlemen with weapons.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What is the matter here?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Zouns, I bleed still, I am hurt, to the death:

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Hold, for your lives.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Hold, hold Lieutenant, sir Montanio, Gentlemen,
Have you forgot all place of sense, and duty:
Hold, the General speaks to you; hold, hold, for shame.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Why how now ho, from whence arises this?
Are we turned Turks, and to ourselves do that
Which Heaven has forbid the Ottamites:
For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl;
He that stirs next, to carve forth his own rage,
Holds his soul light, he dies upon his motion;
Silence that dreadful bell, it frights the Isle
From her propriety: what is the matter masters?
Honest Iago, that looks dead with grieving,
Speak, who began this, on thy love I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I do not know, friends all but now, even now,
In quarter, and in terms, like bride and groom,
Divesting them to bed, and then but now,
As if some planet had unwitted men,
Swords out, and tilting one at others breast,
In opposition bloody. I cannot speak
Any beginning to this peevish odds;
And would in action glorious, I had lost
These legs, that brought me to a part of it.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: How came it Michael, you were thus forgot?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I pray you pardon me, I cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Worthy Montanio, you were wont to be civil,
The gravity and stillness of your youth,
The world hath noted, and your name is great,
In men of wisest censure: what is the matter
That you unlace your reputation thus,
And spend your rich opinion, for the name
Of a night brawler? give me answer to it ?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Worthy Othello, I am hurt to danger,
Your Officer Iago can inform you,
While I spare speech, which something now offends me,
Of all that I do know, nor know I aught
By me, that is said or done amiss this night,
Unless self-charity be sometime a vice,
And to defend ourselves it be a sin,
When violence assails us.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Now by heaven
My blood begins my safer guides to rule,
And passion having my best judgment cooled,
Assays to lead the way. Zouns, if I stir,
Or do but lift this arm, the best of you
Shall sink in my rebuke: give me to know
How this foul rout began, who set it on,
And he that is approved in this offence,
Though he had twinned with me, both at a birth,
Shall lose me; what, in a Town of war,
Yet wild, the people's hearts brim full of fear,
To manage private and domestic quarrels,
In night, and on the Court and guard of safety?
It is monstrous. Iago, who began?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: If partiality affined, or league in office,
Thou dost deliver, more or less than truth,
Thou art no soldier.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Touch me not so near,
I had rather have this tongue out from my mouth,
Than it should do offence to Michael Cassio:
Yet I persuade myself to speak the truth,
Shall nothing wrong him. Thus it is General:
Montanio and myself being in speech,
There comes a fellow, crying out for help,
And Cassio following him with determined sword,
To execute upon him: Sir this Gentleman
Steps in to Cassio, and entreats his pause;
Myself the crying fellow did pursue,
Lest by his clamour, as it so fell out,
The Town might fall in fright: he swift of foot,
Out-ran my purpose: and I returned the rather,
For that I heard the clink and fall of swords:
And Cassio high in oaths, which till tonight,
I never might see before: when I came back,
For this was brief, I found them close together,
At blow and thrust, even as again they were,
When you yourself did part them.
More of this matter can I not report,
But men are men, the best sometimes forget;
Though Cassio did some little wrong to him,
As men in rage strike those that wish them best,
Yet surely Cassio, I believe received
From him that fled, some strange indignity,
Which patience could not pass.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I know Iago,
Thy honesty and love doth mince this matter,
Making it light to Cassio: Cassio, I love thee,
But never more be Officer of mine.
Look if my Gentle love be not raised up:
I will make thee an example.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: All is well now sweeting:
Come away to bed: sir, for your hurts,
Myself will be your surgeon; lead him off;
Iago, look with care about the Town,
And silence those, whom this vile brawl distracted.
Come Desdemona: it is the Soldier's, life,
To have their balmy slumbers waked with strife,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What are you hurt Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Aye, past all surgery.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Marry God forbid.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
Reputation, reputation, I have lost my reputation:
I have lost the immortal part sir of myself,
And what remains is bestial, my reputation,
Iago, my reputation.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
As I am an honest man, I thought you had received some
bodily wound, there is more offence in that than in Reputation: reputation
is an idle and most false imposition, oft got without merit,
and lost without deserving, You have lost no reputation at all, unless
you repute yourself such a loser; what man, there are ways
to recover the General again: you are but now cast in his mood, a
punishment more in policy, than in malice, even so, as one would
beat his offenceless dog, to affright an imperious Lion: sue to
him again, and he is yours.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
I will rather sue to be despised, than to deceive so good a
Commander, with so light, so drunken, and indiscreet an Officer:
O thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known
by, let us call thee Devil.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
What was he, that you followed with your sword?
What had he done to you?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly; a
quarrel, but nothing wherefore. O God, that men should put an
enemy in their, mouths, to steal away their, brains; that we
should with joy, Revel, pleasure, and applause, transform ourselves
into beasts.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Why, but you are now well enough: how came you thus recovered?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
It hath pleased the Devil drunkenness, to give place to
the Devil wrath; one unperfectness, shows me another, to make
me frankly despise myself.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Come, you are too severe a moraler; as the time, the place,
the condition of this Country stands, I could heartily wish, this
had not so befallen; but since it is as it is, mend it, for your own good.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
I will ask him for my place again, he shall tell me I am a
drunkard: had I as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would
stop them all: to be now a sensible man, by and by a fool, and presently
a beast. Every unordinate cup is unblessed, and the ingredience
is a devil.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be
well used; exclaim no more against it; and good Lieutenant, I
think you think I love you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I have well approved it sir, ---I drunk?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
You, or any man living may be drunk at some time: I will
tell you what you shall do, --our General's wife is now the General;
I may say so in this respect, for that he has devoted and given up
himself to the contemplation, mark and devotement of her parts
and graces. Confess yourself freely to her, importune her, she will
help to put you in your place again: she is so free, so kind, so apt,
so blessed a disposition, that she holds it a vice in her goodness,
not to do more than she is requested. This brawl between
you and her husband, entreat her to splinter, and my fortunes
against any lay, worth naming, this crack of your love
shall grow stronger than it was before.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: You advise me well.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: I protest in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
I think it freely, and betimes in the morning, will I beseech
the virtuous Desdemona, to undertake for me; I am desperate
of my fortunes, if they check me here.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
You are in the right:
Good night Lieutenant, I must to the watch.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Good night honest Iago.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: And what is he then, that says I play the villain,
When this advice is free I give, and honest,
Probal to thinking, and indeed the course,
To win the Moore again? For it is most easy
The inclining Desdemona to subdue,
In any honest suite, she is framed as fruitful,
As the free Elements: and then for her
To win the Moore. were it to renounce his baptism,
All seals and symbols of redeemed sin,
His soul is so enfettered to her love,
That she may make, unmake, do what she list,
Even as her appetite shall play the god
With his weak function: how am I then a villain?
To counsel Cassio to this parallel course.
Directly to his good: divinity of hell,
When devils will their blackest sins put on,
They do suggest at first with heavenly shows,
As I do now: for while this honest fool
Plies Desdemona to repair his fortunes,
And she for him, pleads strongly to the Moore:
I will pour this pestilence into his ear,
That she repeals him for her body's lust;
And by how much she strives to do him good,
She shall undo her credit with the Moore,
So will I turn her vertue into pitch,
And out of her own goodness make the net
That shall enmesh them all:

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: How now Roderigo?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
I do follow here in the chase, not like a hound that hunts, but
one that fills up the cry: my money is almost spent, I have been tonight
exceedingly well cudgeled: I think the issue will be, I shall have so
much experience for my pains, as that comes to, and no money at
all, and with that wit return to Venice.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: How poor are they, that have not patience?
What wound did ever heal, but by degrees?
Thou knowest we work by wit, and not by witchcraft,
And wit depends on dilatory time.
Does it not go well? Cassio has beaten thee,
And thou, by that small hurt, hast cashiered Cassio,
Though other things grow fair against the sun,
But fruits that blossom first, will first be ripe,
Content thyself awhile; bi'the mass it is morning;
Pleasure, and action, make the hours seem short:
Retire thee, go where thou art billited,
Away I say, thou shalt know more hereafter:
Nay get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Some things are to be done,
My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress,
I will set her on.
Myself awhile, to draw the Moore apart,
And bring him jump, when he may Cassio find,
Soliciting his wife: Aye, that is the way,
Dull not devise by coldness and delay.

div2.stage: Enter Cassio,with Musitians and the Clowne.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Masters, play here, I will content your pains,
Something that is brief, and bid good morrow General.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why masters, have your instruments been at Naples, that they
speak in the nose thus?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: How sir, how?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Are these I pray, called wind Instruments?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Aye marry are they sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O, thereby hangs a tail.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Whereby hangs a tail sir?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Marry sir, by many a wind Instrument that I know: But
masters here is money for you, and the General so likes your music,
that he desires you of all loves, to make no more noise
with it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Well sir, we will not.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
If you have any music that may not be heard, to it
again, but as they say, to hear music, the General does not
greatly care.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: We have none such sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Then put your pipes in your bag, for I will away; go, vanish away.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Dost thou hear my honest friend?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: No, I hear not your honest friend, I hear you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
Prithee keep up thy quillets, there is a poor piece of
gold for thee: if the Gentlewoman that attends the General's wife
be stirring: tell her there is one Cassio, entreats her a little favour of
speech --- wilt thou do this?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: She is stirring sir, if she will stir hither, I shall seem to notify unto her.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Do good my friend: In happy time Iago.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: You have not been a-bed, then.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Why no, the day had broke before we parted:
I have made bold Iago, to send in to your wife, --my suite to her,
Is, that she will to virtuous Desdemona,
Procure me some access.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I will send her to you presently,
And I will devise a mean to draw the Moore
Out of the way, that your converse and business,
May be more free.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I humbly thank you for it: I never knew
A Florentine more kind and honest:

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Good morrow good Lieutenant, I am sorry
For your displeasure, but all will soon be well,
The General and his wife are talking of it,
And she speaks for you stoutly: the Moore replies,
That he you hurt is of great fame in Cypres,
And great affinity, and that in wholesome wisdom,
He might not but refuse you: but he protests he loves you,
And needs no other suitor but his likings,
To take the safest occasion by the front,
To bring you in again.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Yet I beseech you,
If you think fit, or that it may be done,
Give me advantage of some brief discourse
With Desdemona alone.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Pray you come in,
I will bestow you where you shall have time,
To speak your bosom freely.

div2.stage: Enter Othello, Iago, and other Centlemen.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: These letters give Iago, to the Pilot,
And by him, do my duties to the State;
That done, I will be walking on the works,
Repair there to me.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Well my good Lord, I will do it .

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: This fortification Gentlemen, shall we see it?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We wait upon your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Be thou assured good Cassio, I will do
All my abilities in thy behalf.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Good Madam do, I know it grieves my husband,
As if the case were his.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: O that is an honest fellow: - do not doubt Cassio,
But I will have my Lord and you again,
As friendly as you were.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Bounteous Madam,
Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio,
He is never anything but your true servant.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: O sir, I thank you, you do love my Lord:
You have known him long, and be you well assured,
He shall in strangest, stand no farther off,
Than in a politic distance.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Aye but Lady,
The policy may either last so long,
Or feed upon such nice, and waterish diet,
Or breed itself, so out of circumstance,
That I being absent, and my place supplied,
My General will forget my love and service:

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Do not doubt that before Emillia here,
I give thee warrant of thy place; assure thee
If I do vow a friendship, I will perform it
To the last Article; my Lord shall never rest,
I will watch him tame, and talk him out of patience;
His bed shall seem a school, his board a shrift,
I will intermingle everything he does,
With Cassio's suite; therefore be merry Cassio,
For thy solicitor shall rather die,
Than give thee cause: away.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Madam, here comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Madam, I will take my leave.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why stay and hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Madam not now, I am very ill at ease,
Unfit for mine own purpose.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Well, do your discretion.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Ha, I like not that.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What dost thou say?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord; or if, I know not what.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Was not that Cassio parted from my wife?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Cassio my Lord? -- no sure, I cannot think it,
That he would sneak away so guilty-like,
Seeing you coming.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I do believe it was he.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: How now my Lord,
I have been talking with a suitor here,
A man that languishes in your displeasure.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Who is it. you mean?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why your Lieutenant Cassio, good my Lord,
If I have any grace or power to move you,
His present reconciliation take:
For if he be not one that truly loves you,
That errs in ignorance, and not in cunning,
I have no judgment in an honest face,
I prithee call him back.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Went he hence now?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Yes faith, so humbled,
That he has left part of his griefs with me,
I suffer with him; good love call him back.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Not now sweet Desdemona some other time.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: But shall it. be shortly?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The sooner sweet for you.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Shall it. be tonight at supper?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: No, not tonight.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Tomorrow dinner then?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I shall not dine at home,
I meet the Captains, at the Citadel.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why then tomorrow night, or Tuesday morn,
On Tuesday morn, or night, or Wednesday morn,
I prithee name the time, but let it not
Exceed three days: Ifaith he is penitent,
And yet his trespass, in our common reason,
(Save that they say, the wars must make examples,
Out of her best) is not almost a fault,
To incur a private check: when shall he come?
Tell me Othello: I wonder in my soul,
What you could ask me, that I should deny?
Or stand so muttering on? What Michael Cassio?
That came a-wooing with you, and so many a time
When I have spoke of you dispraisingly,
Hath taken your part, to have so much to do
To bring him in? Byrlady I could do much.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Prithee no more, let him come when he will,
I will deny thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why this is not a boon,
It is as I should entreat you wear your gloves:
Or feed on nourishing dishes, or keep you warm,
Or sue to you, to do a peculiar profit
To your own person: nay, when I have a suite,
Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed,
It shall be full of poise and difficulty,
And fearful to be granted.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I will deny thee nothing,
Whereon I do beseech thee grant me this,
To leave me but a little to myself.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Shall I deny you? no, farewell my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Farewell my Desdomona, I will come to thee straight.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Emillia, come, be it as your fancies teach you,
Whatever you be I am obedient.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Excellent wretch, perdition catch my soul,
But I do love thee, and when I love thee not,
Chaos is come again.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: My noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What dost thou say Iago?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Did Michael Cassio when you wooed my Lady,
Know of your love?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: He did from first to last: -- Why dost thou ask?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: But for a satisfaction of my thoughts.
No further harm.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Why of thy thought Iago?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O yes, and went between us very often.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Indeed? Indeed, discernest thou aught in that?
Is he not honest?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Honest my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Honest? I honest.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: My Lord, for aught I know.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What dost thou think?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Think my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Think my Lord? By heaven he echoes me.
As if there were some monster in his thought:
Too hideous to be shown: thou didst mean something;
I heard thee say but now, thou likest not that
When Cassio left my wife: what didst not like?
And when I told thee, he was of my counsel,
In my whole course of wooing, thou criedest indeed?
And didst contract, and purse thy brow together,
As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain,
Some horrible counsel: if thou dost love me,
Show me thy thought.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: My Lord, you know I love you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I think thou dost,
And for I know, thou art full of love and honesty,
And weighest thy words, before thou give them breath,
Therefore these stops of thine affright me the more:
For such things in a false disloyal knave,
Are tricks of custom; but in a man that is just,
They are close denotements, working from the heart,
That passion cannot rule.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: For Michael Cassio,
I dare presume, I think that he is honest,

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I think so too.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Men should be that they seem,
Or those that be not, would they might seem none.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Certain, men should be what they seem.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Why then I think Cassio is an honest man.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Nay yet there is more in this,
I prithee speak to me to thy thinkings:
As thou dost ruminate, and give the worst of thought,
The worst of word.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Good my Lord pardon me;
Though I am bound to every act of duty,
I am not bound to that all slaves are free to,
Utter my thoughts? Why, say they are vile and false:
As where is that palace, whereunto foul things
Sometimes intrude not? who has a breast so pure,
But some uncleanly apprehensions,
Keep leets and law-days, and in Session sit
With meditations lawful?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Thou dost conspire against thy friend Iago,
If thou but thinkest him wronged, and makest his ear
A stranger to thy thoughts.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I do beseech you,
Though I perchance am vicious in my guess,
As I confess it is my natures plague,
To spy into abuses, and oft my jealousy
Shapes faults that are not, I entreat you then,
From one that so imperfectly connects,
You would take no notice, nor build yourself a trouble,
Out of my scattering, and unsure observance;
It were not for your quiet, nor your good,
Nor for my manhood, honesty, or wisdom,
To let you know my thoughts,

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Zouns.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Good name in man and woman is dear my Lord;
Is the immediate Jewel of our souls:
Who steals my purse, steals trash, it is something, nothing,
It was mine, it is his, and has been slave to thousands:
But he that filches from me my good name,
Robs me of that which not enriches him,
And makes me poor indeed.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: By heaven I will know thy thought.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand,
Nor shall not, whilst it is in my custody:
O beware jealousy.
It is the green-eyed monster, which doth mock
That meat it feeds on. That Cuckold lives in bliss,
Who certain of his fate, loves not his wronger:
But o, what damned minutes tells he over,
Who dotes, yet doubts, suspects, yet strongly loves.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O misery.

sp.speaker: Iag.
