sp.l: Poor and content, is rich, and rich enough,
But riches, fineless, is as poor as winter,
To him that ever fears he shall be poor:
Good God, the souls of all my tribe defend
From jealousy,

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Why, why is this?
Thinkst thou I would make a life of jealousy?
To follow still the changes of the Moon
With fresh suspicions? No, to be once in doubt,
Is once to be resolved: exchange me for a Goat,
When I shall turn the business of my soul
To such exsufflicate, and blown surmises,
Matching thy inference: it is not to make me jealous,
To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company,
Is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances well;
Where vertue is, these are more virtuous:
Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw
The smallest fear, or doubt of her revolt,
For she had eyes, and chose me: no Iago,
I will see before I doubt, when I doubt, prove,
And on the proof, there is no more but this:
Away at once with love or jealousy.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I am glad of it, for now I shall have reason,
To show the love and duty that I bear you,
With franker spirit: therefore as I am bound
Receive it from me: I speak not yet of proof,
Look to your wife, observe her well with Cassio;
Wear your eye thus, not jealous, nor secure,
I would not have your free and noble nature,
Out of self-bounty be abused, look to it :
I know our Country disposition well,
In Venice they do let God see the pranks
They dare show their husbands: their best conscience,
Is not to leave undone, but keep unknown.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Dost thou say so.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: She did deceive her father marrying you;
And when she seemed to shake and fear your looks,
She loved them most.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: And so she did.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Why go to then,
She that so young, could give out such a seeming,
To seal her father's eyes up, close as Oak,
He thought it was witchcraft: but I am much to blame,
I humbly do beseech you of your pardon,
For too much loving you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I am bound to thee forever.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I see this hath a little dashed your spirits.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Not a jot, not a jot.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Ifaith I fear it has.
I hope you will consider what is spoke,
Comes from my love: But I do see you are moved,
I am to pray you, not to strain my speech,
To grosser issues, nor to larger reach,
Than to suspicion.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Should you do so my Lord,
My speech should fall into such vile success,
As my thoughts aim not at: Cassio is my trusty friend:
My Lord, I see you are moved.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: No, not much moved,
I do not think but Desdesmona is honest.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Long live she so, and long live you to think so.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: And yet how nature erring from itself.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Aye, there is the point: as to be bold with you,
Not to affect many proposed matches,
Of her own Clime, complexion, and degree,
Whereto we see in all things, nature tends;
Fie we may smell in such a will, most rank
Foul disproportion: thoughts unnatural.
But pardon me: I do not in position,
Distinctly speak of her, though I may fear
Her will recoiling to her better judgment,
May fall to match you with her country forms,
And happily repent.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Farewell, if more
Thou dost perceive, let me know more, set on
Thy wife to observe: leave me Iago.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: My Lord I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Why did I marry? This honest creature doubtless
Sees and knows more, much more than he unfolds.
My Lord, I would I might entreat your honour,
To scan this thing no further, leave it to time,
Though it be fit, that Cassio have his place,
For sure he fills it up with great ability:
Yet if you please to hold him off awhile,
You shall by that perceive him and his means;
Note if your Lady strain her entertainment,
With any strong or vehement importunity,
Much will be seen in that in the mean time,
Let me be thought too busy in my fears,
As worthy cause I have, to fear I am;
And hold her free, I do beseech your honour.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Fear not my government.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I once more take my leave.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: This fellow is of exceeding honesty,
And knows all qualities, with a learned spirit
Of human dealing: if I do prove her haggard,
Though that her jesses were my dear heart strings,
I would whistle her off, and let her down the wind,
To prey at fortune. Happily, for I am black,
And have not those soft parts of conversation,
That Chamberers have, or for I am declined
Into the vault of years; yet that is not much,
She is gone, I am abused, and my relief
Must be to loathe her: O curse of marriage,
That we can call these delicate creatures ours,
And not their appetites: I had rather be a Toad,
And live upon the vapour in a dungeon,
Than keep a corner in a thing I love,
For others' uses: yet it is the plague of great ones,
Prerogatived are they less than the base,
It is destiny, unshunnable, like death:
Even then this forked plague is fated to us,
When we do quicken: Desdemona comes,
If she be false, O then heaven mocks itself,
I will not believe it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: How now my dear Othello?
Your dinner, and the generous Ilander
By you invited, do attend your presence,

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I am to blame.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why is your speech so faint? are you not well?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I have a pain upon my forehead, here.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Faith that is with watching, it will. away again;
Let me but bind your head, within this hour
It will be well again.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Your napkin is too little:
Let it alone, come I will go in with you.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I am very sorry that you are not well.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I am glad I have found this napkin,
This was her first remembrance from the Moore,
My wayward husband, hath a hundred times
Wooed me to steal it, but she so loves the token,
For he conjured her, she should ever keep it,
That she reserves it ever more about her,
To kiss, and talk to; I will have the work taken out,
And give it. Iago: what he will. do with it,
Heaven knows, not I,
I nothing know, but for his fantasy.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: How now, what do you here alone?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Do not you chide, I have a thing for you.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: A thing for me, it is a common thing.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: To have a foolish thing.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O, is that all? what will you give me now,
For that same handkercher?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What handkercher?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What handkercher?
Why that the Moore first gave to Desdemona,
That which so often you did bid me steal.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Hast stole it from her?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No faith, she let it drop by negligence,
And to the advantage, I being here, took it. up:
Look here it is.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: A good wench, give it me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What will you do with it, that you have been
So earnest to have me filch it?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Why, what is that to you?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: If it be not for some purpose of import,
Give me it. again, poor Lady, she will run mad,
When she shall lack it.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Be not you known of it, I have use for it: --go leave me;
I will in Cassio's Lodging lose this napkin,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: And let him find it: trifles light as air,
Are to the jealous, confirmations strong
As proofs of holy writ, this may do something,
Dangerous conceits are in their natures poisons,
Which at the first are scarce found to distaste.
But with a little art, upon the blood,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Burn like the minds of sulphur: I did say so:
look where he comes, not Poppy, nor Mandragora,
Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world,
Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep,
Which thou owedst yesterday.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Ha, ha, false to me, to me?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Why how now General? no more of that.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Avaunt, be gone, thou hast set me on the rack,
I swear, it is better to be much abused,
Than but to know a little.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: How now my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What sense had I of her stolen hours of lust:
I saw it not, thought it not, it harmed not me,
I slept the next night well, was free, and merry;
I found not Cassio's kisses on her lips,
He that is robbed, not wanting what is stolen,
Let him not know it, and he is not robbed at all.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I am sorry to hear this.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I had been happy if the general Camp,
Pioneers, and all, had tasted her sweet body,
So I had nothing known: O now forever
Farewell the tranquil mind, farewell content:
Farewell the plumed troop, and the big wars.
That makes ambition vertue: O farewell,
Farewell the neighing Steed, and the shrill Trump,
The spirit-stirring Drum, the ear-piercing Fife;
The royal Banner, and all quality,
Pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war.
And O ye mortal Engines, whose wide throats,
The immortal Jove's great clamour counterfeit;
Farewell, Othello's Occupation is gone.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Is it possible my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Villain, be sure you prove my Love a whore,
Be sure of it, give me the ocular proof,
Or by the worth of man's eternal soul,
Thou hadst been better have been borne a dog,
Than answer my waked wrath.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Is it come to this?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Make me to see it, or at the least so prove it,
That the probation, bear no hinge, nor loop,
To hang a doubt on: or woe upon thy life.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: My noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: If thou dost slander her, and torture me,
Never pray more, abandon all remorse.
On horror's head, horrors accumulate:
Do deeds, to make heaven weep, all earth amazed,
For nothing canst thou to damnation add greater than that.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: O grace, O heaven defend me,
Are you a man, have you a soul or sense?
God buy, you take thine office, -- O wretched fool,
That livest to make thine honesty a vice,
O monstrous world, take note, take note, O world,
To be direct and honest, is not safe,
I thank you for this profit, and from hence,
I will love no friend, since love breeds such offence.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Nay stay, thou shouldst be honest.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I should be wise, for honesty is a fool,
And loses that it works for:
I see sir, you are eaten up with passion,
I do repent me that I put it to you,
You would be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Would, nay, I will.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: And may, but how, how satisfied my Lord?
Would you, the supervisor grossly gape on,
Behold her topped?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Death and damnation --o..

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: It were a tedious difficulty I think,
To bring them to that prospect, dam them then,
If ever mortal eyes did see them bolster
More than their own; what then, how then?
What shall I say? where is satisfaction?
It is impossible you should see this.
Were they as prime as Goats, as hot as Monkeys,
As salt as Wolves, in pride; and fools as gross,
As ignorance made drunk: But yet I say,
If imputation and strong circumstances,
Which lead directly to the door of truth,
Will give you satisfaction, you may have it.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Give me a living reason, that she is disloyal.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I do not like the office,
But sith I am entered into this cause so far,
Pricked to it by foolish honesty and love,
I will go on: I lay with Cassio lately,
And being troubled with a raging tooth, I could not sleep.
There are a kind of men so loose of soul,
That in their sleeps will mutter their affairs,
One of this kind is Cassio:
In sleep I heard him say. Sweet Desdemona,
Let us be merry, let us hide our loves;
And then sir, would he gripe and wring my hand,
Cry out, sweet creature, and then kiss me hard,
As if he plucked up kisses by the roots,
That grew upon my lips, then laid his
leg
Over my thigh, and sighed, and kissed, and then
Cried, cursed fate, that gave thee to the Moore.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O Monstrous, monstrous.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Nay, this was but his dream.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: But this devoted a fore-gone conclusion,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: It is a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream,
And this may help to thicken other proofs,
That do demonstrate thinly.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I will tear her all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Nay, but be wise, yet we see nothing done,
She may be honest yet, tell me but this,
Have you not sometimes seen a handkercher,
Spotted with strawberries in your wife's hand.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I gave her such a one, it was my first gift.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I know not that but such a handkercher,
I am sure it was your wife's, did I today
See Cassio wipe his beard with.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: If it. be that.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: If it be that or any, it was hers,
It speaks against her, with the other proofs.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O that the slave had forty thousand lives,
One is too poor, too weak for my revenge:
Now do I see it is time, look here Iago,
All my fond love, thus do I blow to heaven, -- it is gone.
Arise black vengeance, from thy hollow Cell,
Yield up O love thy crown, and hearted Throne,
To tyrannous hate, swell bosom with thy fraught,
For it is of Aspic's tongues.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Pray be content.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O blood, Iago, blood.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Patience I say, your mind perhaps may change.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Never:
In the due reverence of a sacred vow,
I here engage my words.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Do not rise yet:
Witness you ever burning lights above,
You Elements that clip us round about,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Witness that here, Iago doth give up
The excellency of his wit, hand, heart,
To wronged Othello's service: let him command,
And to obey, shall be remorse,
What bloody work soever.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I greet thy love:
Not with vain thanks, but with acceptance bounteous,
And will upon the instant put thee to it ,
Within these three days, let me hear thee say,
That Cassio is not alive,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: My friend is dead:
It is done as you request, but let her live.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Dam her lewd minks: O dam her,
Come, go with me apart, I will withdraw
To furnish me with some swift means of death,
For the fair devil: now art thou my Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I am your own forever.

div2.stage: Enter Desdemonia Emilla and the Clowne.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Do you know sirrah, where the Lieutenant Cassio lies?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I dare not say he lies anywhere.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Why man?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: He is a Soldier, and for one to say a Soldier lies, is stabbing.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Go to, where lodges he?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a lodging,
and say he lies there, were to lie in my throat.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.p: Can you inquire him out, and be edified by report?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I will catechise the world for him, that is, make questions
And by them answer.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.p:
Seek him, bid him come hither, tell him I have moved my
Lord in his behalf, and hope all will be well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
To do this is within the compass of a man, and therefore
I will attempt the doing of it.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Where should I lose that handkercher Emillia?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I know not Madam.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Believe me, I had rather lose my purse
Full of Crusadoes: and but my noble Moore
Is true of mind, and made of no such baseness,
As jealous creatures are, it were enough,
To put him to ill thinking.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Is he not jealous:

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Who he? I think the Sun where he was borne,
Drew all such humours from him.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Look were he comes.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I will not leave him now,
Let Cassio be called to him: how is it with you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Well my good Lady: O hardness to dissemble:
How do you Desdemona?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Well, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Give me your hand, this hand is moist my Lady.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: It yet has felt no age, nor known no sorrow.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: This argues fruitfulness and liberal heart,
Not hot and moist, this hand of yours requires
A sequester from liberty: fasting and praying,
Much castigation, exercise devout;
For here is a young and sweating devil here,
That commonly rebels: it is a good hand,
A frank one.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: You may indeed say so,
For it was that hand that gave away my heart.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: A liberal hand, the hearts of old gave hands,
But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I cannot speak of this, come, come, your promise.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What promise chuck?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I have a salt and sullen rheum offends me,
Lend me thy handkercher,

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That which I gave you.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I have it not about me.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Not.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: No faith my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That is a fault: that handkercher
Did an Egyptian to my mother give,
She was a charmer, and could almost read
The thoughts of people; she told her while she kept it,
It would make her amiable, and subdue my father
Entirely to her love: But if she lost it,
Or made a gift of it: my father's eye
Should hold her loathly, and his spirits should hunt
After new fancies: she dying, gave it me,
And bid me when my fate would have me wive,
To give it her; I did so, and take heed of it,
Make it a darling, like your precious eye,
To lose, or give it away, were such perdition,
As nothing else could match.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is true, there is magic in the web of it,
A Sibyl that had numbered in the world,
The Sun to make two hundred compasses,
In her prophetic fury, sowed the work;
The worms were hallowed that did breed the silk,
And it was died in Mummy, with the skilful
Conserves of maidens hearts.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Ifaith is it. true?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Most veritable, therefore look to it well.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Then would to God, that I had never seen it.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Ha, wherefore?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why do you speak so starting and rashly.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Is it lost? is it. gone? speak, is it out of the way?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Heaven bless us.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is not lost, but what and if it were?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: No faith my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I say it is not lost.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Fetch it, let me see it,

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Why so I can sir, but I will not now,
This is a trick, to put me from my suite,
I pray let Cassio, be received again.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Fetch me that handkercher, my mind misgives.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Come, come, you will never meet a more sufficient man.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The handkercher.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I pray talk me of Cassio.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The handkercher.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: A man that all his time,
Hath founded his good fortunes on your love,
Shared dangers with you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The handkercher.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Ifaith you are to blame.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Zouns.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Is not this man jealous?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I never saw this before:
Sure there is some wonder in this handkercher,
I am most unhappy in the loss.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: It is not a year or two shows us a man,
They are all but stomachs, and we all but food;
They eat us hungrily, and when they are full,
They belch us; look you, Cassio and my husband.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: There is no other way, it is she must do it,
And lo the happiness, go, and importune her.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: How now good Cassio, what is the news with you?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Madam, my former suite: I do beseech you,
That by your virtuous means, I may again
Exist, and be a member of his love,
Whom I, with all the duty of my heart,
Entirely honour, I would not be delayed:
If my offence be of such mortal kind,
That neither service past, nor present sorrows,
Nor purposed merit, in futurity
Can ransom me, into his love again
But to know so, must be my benefit,
So shall I cloth me in a forced content,
And shoot myself up in some other course,
To fortune's alms.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Alas thrice gentle Cassio,
My advocation is not now in tune;
My Lord is not my Lord, nor should I know him,
Were he in favour, as in humour altered.
So help me, every spirit sanctified,
As I have spoken for you, all my best,
And stood within the blank of his displeasure,
For my free speech: you must a while be patient,
What I can do I will, and more I will
Than for myself I dare, let that suffice you.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Is my Lord angry?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: He went hence but now,
And certainly in strange unquietness.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Can he be angry? I have seen the Cannon,
When it hath blown his ranks into the air;
And (like the Devil) from his very arm,
Puffed his own brother, and can he be angry?
Something of moment then: I will go meet him,
There is matter in it indeed, if he be angry.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I prithee do so: something sure of State,
Either from Venice, or some unhatched practice,
Made demonstrable here in Cypres to him,
Hath puddled his clear spirit, and in such cases
Men's natures wrangle with inferior things,
Though great ones are the object,
It is even so: for let our finger ache,
And it endues our other heathful members,
Even to that sense of pain; nay, we must think,
Men are not gods,
Nor of them look for such observances
As fits the Bridal: beshrew me much Emillia,
I was (unhandsome, warrior as I am)
Arraigning his unkindness with my soul;
But now I find, I had suborned the witness,
And he is indicted falsely.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Pray heaven it be State matters, as you think,
And no conception, nor no jealous toy
Concerning you.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Alas the day, I never gave him cause.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But jealous souls will not be answered so,
They are not ever jealous for the cause,
But jealous for they are jealous: it is a monster,
Begot upon itself, borne on itself.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Heaven keep that monster from Othello's mind.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Lady, Amen.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: I will go seek him, Cassio, walk here about,
If I do find him fit, I will move your suite,
And seek to effect it to my uttermost.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Ladyship.

div2.stage: Exeunt DESDEMONA and EMILIA Enter Bianca.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Save you friend Cassio.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: What make you from home?
How is it with you my most fair Bianca?
Ifaith sweet love I was coming to your house.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: And I was going to your Lodging Cassio;
What, keep a week away? seven days and nights,
Eight-score eight hours, and lover's absent hours,
More tedious than the dial, eight-score times,
No weary reckoning.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Pardon me Bianca,
I have this while with laden thoughts been pressed,
But I shall in a more convenient time,
Strike off this score of absence: sweet Bianca,
Take me this work out.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: O. Cassio, whence came this?
This is some token from a newer friend,
To the felt absence, now I feel a cause,
Is it come to this?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Go to woman,
Throw your vile guesses in the devil's teeth,
From whence you have them, you are jealous now,
That this is from some mistress, some remembrance,
No by my faith Bianca,

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Why whose is it?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I know not sweet, I found it in my chamber,
I like the work well, ere it be demanded,
As like enough it will, I would have it copied,
Take it, and do it , and leave me for this time.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Leave you, wherefore?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I do attend here on the General,
And think it no addition, nor my wish,
To have him see me womaned.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: But that you do not love me:
I pray you bring me on the way a little,
And say, if I shall see you soon at night.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: It is but a little way, that I can bring you,
For I attend here, but I will see you soon.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: It is very good, I must be circumstanced.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Will you think so?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Think so Iago.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What, to kiss in private?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: An unauthorised kiss.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Or to be naked with her friend a-bed,
An hour, or more, not meaning any harm.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Naked a-bed Iago, and not mean harm?
It is hypocrisy against the devil:
They that mean virtuously, and yet do so,
The devil their vertue tempts, and they tempt heaven.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: So they do nothing, it is a venial slip;
But if I give my wife a handkercher.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Why then it is hers my Lord, and being hers,
She may, I think, bestow it on any man.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: She is protectress of her honour too,
May she give that?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Her honour is an essence that is not seen,
They have it very oft, that have it not:
But for the handkercher.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it:
Thou saidst (O it comes over my memory,
As doth the Raven over the infected house,
Boding to all.) He had my handkercher.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Aye, what of that?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That is not so good now.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What if I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
Or heard him say (as knaues be such abroad)
Who having by their own importunate suite,
Or by the voluntary dotage of some mistress,
Convinced, or supplied them, cannot choose,
But they must blab.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Hath he said anything?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: He hath my Lord, but be you well assured,
No more than he will unswear.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What hath he said?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Faith that he did --I know not what he did.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Lie.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: With her?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: With her, on her, what you will.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
Lie with her, lie on her? We say lie on her, when they belie
her; lie with her, Zouns, that is fulsome, handkerchers, Confession,
hankerchers.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Work on my medicine, work: thus credulous fools are
caught, and many worthy and chaste dames, even thus all guiltless,
meet reproach; What ho my Lord, my Lord I say, Othello,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: how now Cassio.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: My Lord is fallen into an Epilepsy,
This is his second fit, he had one yesterday.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Rub him about the Temples.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: No, forbear,
The Lethargy, must have his quiet course,
If not he foams at mouth, and by and by
Breaks out to savage madness: look he stirs:
Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
He will recover straight, when he is gone,
I would on great occasion speak with you.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: How is it General, have you not hurt your head?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Dost thou mock me?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I mock you? no by Heaven,
Would you would bear your fortunes like a man.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: A horned man is a monster, and a beast.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: There is many a beast then in a populous City,
And many a civil monster.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Did he confess?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Good sir be a man,
Think every bearded fellow, that is but yoked,
May draw with you, there is millions now alive,
That nightly lies in those unproperly beds,
Which they dare swear peculiar: your case is better:
O it is the spite of hell, the fiends arch mock,
To lip a wanton in a secure Coach,
And to suppose her chaste: No, let me know,
And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O thou art wise, it is certain.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Stand you awhile apart,
Confine yourself but in a patient list:
Whilst you were here ere while, mad with your grief,
A passion most unsuiting such a man,
Cassio came hither, I shifted him away,
And laid good scuse, upon your ecstasy,
Bid him anon retire, and here speak with me,
The which he promised: but encave yourself,
And mark the Jeers, the Jibes, and notable scorns,
That dwell in every region of his face;
For I will make him tell the tale anew,
Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when,
He has, and is again to cope your wife:
I say, but mark his gesture, marry patience,
Or I shall say, you are all in all, in spleen,
And nothing of a man.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Dost thou hear Iago,
I will be found most cunning in my patience;
But dost thou hear, most bloody.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: That is not amiss:
But yet keep time in all; will you withdraw?
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca;
A housewife that by selling her desires,
Buys herself bread and clothes: it is a Creature,
That dotes on Cassio: as it is the strumpets plague
To beguile many, and be beguiled by one,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain
From the excess of laughter: here he comes:
As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad,
And his unbookish jealousy must conster
Poor Cassio's smiles, gestures, and light behaviour,
Quite in the wrong: How do you now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The worser, that you give me the addition,
Whose want even kills me.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure of it.
Now if this suite lay in Bianca's power,
How quickly should you speed.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Alas poor Caitiff.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Look how he laughs already.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I never knew a woman love man so.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Alas poor rogue, I think ifaith she loves me.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Do you hear Cassio?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Now he importunes him to tell it on,
Go to, well said.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: She gives it out that you shall marry her,
Do you intend it?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Do you triumph Roman, do you triumph?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
I marry her? I prithee bear some charity to my wit,
Do not think it so unwholesome: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: So, so, so, so, laugh that wins.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Faith the cry goes, you shall marry her.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Prithee say true.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: I am a very villain else,

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Ha you stored me well.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
This is the monkey's own giving out; she is persuaded I will
marry her, out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Iago beckons me, now he begins the story.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
She was here even now, she haunts me in every place, I
was the other day, talking on the sea bank, with certain Venetians, and
thither comes this bauble, by this hand she falls thus about my neck.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Crying, O dear Cassio, as it were: his gesture imports it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p:
So hangs, and lolls, and weeps upon me; so hales, and pulls
me, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
Now he tells how she plucked him to my Chamber,
I see that nose of yours, but not that dog I shall throw it to.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Well, I must leave her company.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Before me, look where she comes,
It is such another ficho; marry a perfumed one, what do you mean
by this haunting of me.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p:
Let the devil and his dam haunt you, what did you mean
by that same handkercher, you gave me even now? I was a fine
fool to take it; I must take out the whole work, a likely piece of
work, that you should find it in your chamber, and not know who
left it there: this is some minx's token, and I must take out the
work; there, give it the hobby horse, wheresoever you had it, I will
take out no work of it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: How now my sweet Bianca, how now, how now?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: By heaven that should be my handkercher.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p:
If you will come to supper tonight, you may, if you will
not, come when you are next prepared for.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: After her, after her.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Faith I must, she will rail in&H4; the street else.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Will you sup there?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Faith I intend so.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Well, I may chance to see you, for I would very fain speak
with you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Prithee come, will you?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Go to, say no more.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: How shall I murder him Iago?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Did you perceive, how he laughed at his vice?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: O Iago,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: And did you see the handkercher?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Was that mine?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
I would have him nine years a-killing; a fine woman, a fair
woman, a sweet woman.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Nay you must forget.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
And let her rot and perish, and be damned tonight, for she
shall not live: no, my heart is turned to stone; I strike it, and it hurts
my hand: O the world has not a sweeter creature, she might lie by
an Emperor's side, and command him tasks.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Nay that is not your way.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
Hang her, I do but say what she is: So delicate with her
needle, an admirable musician, O she will sing the savageness
out of a Bear; of so hie and plenteous wit and invention.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: She is the worse for all this.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: A thousand thousand times: and then of so gentle a condition.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Aye, too gentle.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Aye that is certain, but yet the pity of it Iago, the pity.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
If you be so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend,
for if it touches not you, it comes near nobody.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: I will chop her into messes ---cuckold me!

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: O it is foul in her.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: With mine Officer.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: That is fouler.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
Get me some poison Iago, this night I will not expostulate
with her, lest her body and beauty unprovide my mind again, this
night Iago.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Do it not with poison, strangle her in her bed, even the
bed she hath contaminated.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Good, good, the justice of it pleases very good.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker: you shall hear
more by midnight.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Excellent good:

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: What Trumpet is that same?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Something from Venice sure, it is Lodouico,
Come from the Duke, and see your wife is with him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: God save the worthy General.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: With all my heart sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The Duke and Senators of Venice greet you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: I kiss the instrument of their pleasures.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: And what is the news good cousin Lodouico?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: I am very glad to see you Seignior: --welcome to Cypres

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I thank you, how does Lieutenant Cassio?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Lives sir

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Cousin, there is fallen between him and my Lord,
An unkind breach, but you shall make all well

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Are you sure of that?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: My Lord

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: This fail you not to do, as you will

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He did not call, he is busy in the paper:
Is there division between thy Lord and Cassio?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: A most unhappy one, I would do much
To atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Fire and Brimstone

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: My Lord

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Are you wise?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: What, is he angry?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Maybe the letter moved him;
For as I think, they do command him home,
Deputing Cassio in his government

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: By my troth, I am glad of it

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Indeed

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: My Lord

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I am glad to see you mad

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: How sweet Othello?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I have not deserved this

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My Lord, this would not be believed in Venice,
Though I should swear I saw it: it is very much,
Make her amends, she weeps

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O Devil, Devil,
If that the earth could teem with women's tears
Each drop she falls, would prove a Crocodile:
Out of my sight

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I will not stay to offend you

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Truly an obedient Lady:
I do beseech your Lordship, call her back

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: My Lord

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What would you with her sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who, I my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Aye, you did wish that I would make her turn:
Sir she can turn, and turn, and yet go on,
And turn again, and she can weep sir, weep;
And she is obedient, as you say, obedient;
Very obedient, proceed you in your tears,
Concerning this sir: O well painted passion:
I am commanded here: -- get you away,
I will send for you anon: -- Sir, I obey the mandate,
And will return to Venice: ---hence, avaunt,
Cassio shall have my place; and sir tonight
I do entreat that we may sup together,
You are welcome sir to Cypres, --goates and monkeys

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is this the noble Moore, whom our full Senate
Call all in all sufficient? This the noble nature,
Whom passion could not shake? Whose solid vertue,
The shot of accident, nor dart of chance
Could neither graze, nor pierce?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: He is much changed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Are his wits safe? is he not light of brain?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: He is that he is, I may not breathe my censure,
What he might be, if as he might, he is not,
I would to heaven he were.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What, strike his wife.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Faith that was not so well; yet would I knew
That stroke would prove the worst.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is it his use?
Or did the letters work upon his blood.
And new create this fault?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Alas, alas.
It is not honesty in me to speak,
What I have seen and known, you shall observe him,
And his own courses will denote him so,
That I may save my speech: do but go after,
And mark how he continues.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: You have seen nothing then.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Yes, and you have seen Cassio and she together.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard
Each syllable that breath made up between them.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What, did they never whisper?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Never, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Nor send you out of the way?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: To fetch her fan, her mask, her gloves, nor nothing?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Never, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That is strange.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I durst my Lord, to wager she is honest,
Lay down my soul at stake: if you think other,
Remove your thought, it doth abuse your bosom,
If any wretch have put this in your head,
Let heavens requite it with the Serpent's curse.
For if she be not honest, chaste, and true,
There is no man happy, the purest of her Sex
Is foul as slander.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Bid her come hither, go,
She says enough, yet she is a simple bawd,
That cannot say as much: this is a subtle whore,
A closet, lock and key, of villainous secrets
And yet she will kneel and pray, I have seen her do it .

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: My Lord, what is your will?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Pray chuck come hither.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: What is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Let me see your eyes --looke in my face.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: What horrible fancy is this?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Some of your function mistress,
Leave procreants alone, and shut the door,
Cough, or cry hem, if any body come,
Your mystery, your mystery: nay dispatch.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Upon my knees, what does your speech import?
I understand a fury in your words,
But not the words

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Why, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Your wife my Lord, your true and loyal wife

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Come, swear it, damn thyself,
lest being like one of heaven, the devils themselves
Should fear to cease thee, therefore be double damned
Swear thou art honest

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Heaven doth truly know it

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Heaven truly knows, that thou art false as hell

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: To whom, my Lord, with whom? how am I false?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O Desdemona, away, away, away

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Alas the heavy day, why do you weep?
Am I the occasion of those tears my Lord?
If haply you my father do suspect,
An Instrument of this your calling back,
Lay not your blame on me; if you have left him,
Why I have left him too

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Had it pleased heaven
To try me with affliction, had he rammed
All kinds of sores, and shames on my bare head,
Steeped me in poverty, to the very lips,
Given to captivity, me and my hopes,
I should have found in some part of my soul
A drop of patience; but alas, to make me
A fixed figure, for the time of scorn,
To point his slow unmoving fingers at -- o., o.,
Yet could I bear that too, well, very well
But there: where I have garnered up my heart,
Where either I must live, or bear no life,
The fountain, from the which my currant runs,
Or else dries up, to be discarded thence,
Or keep it as a Cistern, for foul Toads
To knot and gender in: turn thy complexion there,
Patience thy young and rose-lipped Cherubim,
I here look grim as Hell

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I hope my noble Lord esteems me honest

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O Aye, as summer's flies, are in the shambles,
That quicken even with blowing:
O thou black weed, why art so lovely fair?
Thou smellest so sweet, that the sense aches at thee,
Would thou hadst never been borne

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book,
Made to write whore on? --- What, committed?
Heaven stops the nose at it, and the Moon winks,
The bawdy wind, that kisses all it meets,
Is hushed within the hallow mine of earth,
And will not hear it: -- what committed, - impudent strumpet

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: By heaven you do me wrong

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Are not you a strumpet?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: No, as I am a Christian:
If to preserve this vessel for my Lord,
From any hated foul unlawful touch,
Be not to be a strumpet, I am none

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What, not a whore?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: No, as I shall be saved

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: O heaven forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I cry you mercy,
I took you for that cunning whore of Venice,
That married with Othello: you mistress,
That have the office opposite to Saint Peter,
And keeps the gates in hell, Aye, you, you, you;
We have done our course; there is money for your pains,
I pray you turn the key, and keep our counsel.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Alas, what does this Gentleman conceive?
How do you Madam, how do you my good Lady?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Faith half asleep.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Good Madam, what is the matter with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: With who?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why with my Lord Madam.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I have none, do not talk to me Emillia,
I cannot weep, nor answer have I none,
But what should go by water: prithee tonight
Lay on my bed our wedding sheets, remember,
And call thy husband hither.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Here is a change indeed.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: It is meet I should be used so, very well;
How have I been behaved, that he might stick
The smallest opinion, on my greatest abuse.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What is your pleasure Madam,
How is it. with you?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I cannot tell: those that do teach young babes
Do it with gentle means, and easy tasks,
He might have chid me so, for in good faith,
I am a child at chiding

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What is the matter Lady?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Alas Iago, my Lord hath so bewhored her,
Thrown such despite, and heavy terms upon her,
As true hearts cannot bear

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Am I that name Iago?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What name fair Lady?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Such as she says my Lord did say I was?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: He called her whore: A beggar in his drink,
Could not have laid such terms upon his Callet

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Why did he so?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I do not know, I am sure I am none such

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Do not weep, do not weep: alas the day

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Has she forsook so many noble matches,
Her Father, and her Country, all her friends,
To be called whore? would it not make one weep?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: It is my wretched fortune

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Beshrew him for it; how comes this trick upon him?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Nay, heaven doth know

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I will be hanged, if some eternal villain,
Some busy and insinuating rogue,
Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office,
Have not devised this slander, I will be hanged else

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Fie, there is no such man, it is impossible

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: If any such there be, heaven pardon him

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: A halter pardon him, and hell gnaw his bones:
Why should he call her whore? who keeps her company?
What place, what time, what form, what likelihood?
The Moor is abused by some outrageous knave:
Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow,
O heaven, that such companions thou wouldst unfold,
And put in every honest hand a whip,
To lash the rascal naked through the world,
Even from the East to the West

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Speak within doors

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O fie upon him; some such squire he was,
That turned your wit, the seamy side without,
And made you to suspect me with the Moore

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: You are a fool, go to

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: O Good Iago,
What shall I do to win my Lord again?
Good friend go to him, for by this light of heaven,
I know not how I lost him

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I pray you be content, it is but his humour,
The business of the State does him offence,
And he does chide with you

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: If it were no other

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: It is but so, I warrant you,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Hark how these Instruments summon you to supper,
And the great Messengers of Venice stay,
Go in, and weep not, all things shall be well.

div2.stage: Exeunt DESDEMONA and EMILIA Enter Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: How now Roderigo?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I do not find that thou dealest justly with me

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What in the contrary?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
Every day, thou dofftest me, with some devise Iago;
And rather, as it seems to me, thou keepest from me,
All conveniency, then suppliest me, with the least
Advantage of hope: I will indeed no longer endure it,
Nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace, what already
I have foolishly suffered

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Will you hear me Roderigo?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
Faith I have heard too much, for your words,
And performance are no kin together

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: You charge me most unjustly

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
I have wasted myself out of means: the Jewels you have
had from me, to deliver to Desdemona, would half have corrupted
a Votarist: you have told me she has received them, and returned me
expectation, and comforts, of sudden respect, and acquittance, but
I find none

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Well, go to, very good

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
Very well, go to, I cannot go to man, it is not very well,
by this hand, I say it is very scurvy, and begin to find myself fopped
in it

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: Very well

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
I say it is not very well: I will make myself known to
Desdemona, if she will return me my Jewels, I will give over my
suite, and repent my unlawful solicitation, if not, assure yourself
I will seek satisfaction of you

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: You have said now

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
Aye, and I have said nothing, but what I protest intendment
of doing

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Why now I see there is mettle in thee, and even from this
time do build on thee, a better opinion than ever before, give me
thy hand Roderigo: Thou hast taken against me a most just conception,
but yet I protest, I have dealt most directly in thy affairs

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: It hath not appeared

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your suspicion is
not without wit and judgment: But Roderigo, if thou hast that
within thee indeed, which I have greater reason to believe now,
than ever, I mean purpose, courage, and valour, this night show it, if
thou the next night following enjoyed not Desdemona, take me
from this world with treachery, and devise engines for my life

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Well, is it within reason and compass?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Sir, there is especial command come from Venice,
To depute Cassio in Othello's place

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
Is that true? why then Othello and Desdemona
Return again to Venice

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
O no, he goes into Mauritania, and takes away with him
The fair Desdemona, unless his abode be lingered
Here by some accident, wherein none can be so
determinate, as the removing of Cassio

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: How do you mean removing of him?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Why, by making him uncapable of Othello's place,
Knocking out his brains

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: And that you would have me to do

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p:
Aye, and if you dare do yourself a profit, and right, he sups
tonight with a harlot, and thither will I go to him; --- he knows
not yet of his honourable fortune: if you will watch his going
thence, which I will fashion to fall out between twelve and one,
you may take him at your pleasure: I will be near to second your
attempt, and he shall fall between us: come, stand not amazed
at it, but go along with me, I will show you such a necessity in his
death, that you shall think yourself bound to put it on him
now high supper time, and the night grows to waste: about it

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I will hear further reason for this

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.p: And you shall be satisfied

div2.stage: Enter Othello, Desdemona, Lodouico, Emillia, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I do beseech you sir, trouble yourself no further.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O pardon me, it shall do me good to walk.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Madam, good night, I humbly thank your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Your honour is most welcome.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Will you walk sir: ---O Desdemona.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
Get you to bed, on the instant I will be returned, forthwith,
dispatch your Attendant there, ---looke it be done.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I will my Lord

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: How goes it now? he looks gentler than he did

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: He says he will return incontinent:
He hath commanded me to go to bed,
And bad me to dismiss you

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Dismiss me?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: It was his bidding, therefore good Emillia,
Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu,
We must not now displease him

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I would you had never seen him

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: So would not I, my love doth so approve him,
That even his stubborning, his checks and frowns
Prithee unpin me; have grace and favour in them

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I have laid these sheets you bade me, on the bed

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: All is one good faith: how foolish are our minds?
If I do die before thee, prithee shroud me
In one of those same sheets

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Come, come, you talk

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: My mother had a maid called Barbary,
She was in love, and he she loved, proved mad,
And did forsake her, she has a song of willow,
An old thing it was, but it expressed her fortune,
And she died singing it, that Song tonight,
Will not go from my mind -- hark, who is that knocks?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: It is the wind

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Now get thee gone, good night:
Mine eyes do itch, does that bode weeping?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: It is neither here nor there

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Wouldst thou do such a deed, for all the world?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why would not you

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: No, by this heavenly light

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p:
Nor I neither, by this heavenly light,
I might do it as well in the dark

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Would thou do such a thing for all the world?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p:
The world is a huge thing, it is a great price,
For a small vice

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Good troth I think thou wouldst not

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p:
By my troth I think I should, and undo it when I had done
it, marry I would not do such a thing for a joint ring; or for measures
of Lawn, nor for Gowns, or Petticoats, nor Caps, nor any
such exhibition; but for the whole world? vds pity, who would
not make her husband a Cuckold, to make him a Monarch? I should
venture purgatory for it

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong,
For the whole world

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p:
Why, the wrong is but a wrong in the world; and having the
world for your labour, it is a wrong in your own world, and you
might quickly make it right

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I do not think there is any such woman

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Yes, a dozen, and as many to the vantage, as would store
the world they played for

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Good night, good night: God me such usage send,
Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Here stand behind this Bulk, straight will he come,
Wear thy good Rapier bare, and put it home,
Quick, quick, fear nothing, I will be at thy elbow;
It makes us or it mars us, think of that
And fix most firm thy resolution.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Be near at hand, I may miscarry in it.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Here at thy hand, be bold, and take thy sword.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I have no great devotion to the dead;
And yet he has given me satisfying reasons,
It is but a man gone: forth my sword, he dies.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I have rubbed this young gnat almost to the sense,
And he grows angry now: whether he kill Cassio,
Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
Every way makes my game; live Roderigo,
He calls me to a restitution large,
For Gold and Jewels, that I bobbed from him,
As gifts to Desdemona:
It must not be, if Cassio do remain,
He has a daily beauty in his life,
That makes me ugly: and besides, the Moore
May unfold me to him; there stand I in peril:
No, he must die, be it so, I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I know his gate, it is he, villain thou diest.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: That thrust had been my enemy indeed,
But that my coat is better than thou thinkst,
I will make proof of thine.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O I am slain.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I am mind forever, light ho, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: The voice of Cassio, Iago keeps his word.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O villain that I am.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Hark it is even so.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O help ho, light, a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is he, O brave Iago, honest and Just,
That hast such noble sense of thy friend's wrong,
Thou teachest me; -- minion, your dear lies dead,
And your fate hies apace; strumpet I come;
Forth of my heart, those charms thine eyes are blotted,
Thy bed lust-stained, shall with lusts blood be spotted.

div2.stage: Exit Othello. Enter Lodouico and Gratiano.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: What ho, no watch, no passage, murder, murder

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: It is some mischance, the cry is very direful.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O help.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O wretched villain.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Two or three groans, it is a heavy night,
These may be counterfeits, let us think it unsafe
To come into the cry without more help.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nobody come, then shall I bleed to death.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Here is one comes in his shirt, with lights and weapons,

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Who is there? whose noise is this, that cries on murder

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I do not know

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Did not you hear a cry?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Here, here, for heaven's sake help me

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What is the matter

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: This is Othello's Ancient, as I take it

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The same indeed, a very valiant fellow

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What are you here, that cry so grievously?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Iago, O I am spoiled, undone by villains,
Give me some help

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: O my Lieutenant: what villains have done this?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I think the one of them is here about,
And cannot make away

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: O treacherous villains:
What are you there? come in and give some help

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O, help me here

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: That is one of them

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: O murderous slave, O villain

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O damned Iago, O inhuman dog, --o, o, o

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Kill him in the dark? where be those bloody thieves?
How silent is this Town? Ho, murder, murder:
What may you be, are you of good or evil?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: As you shall prove us, praise us

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Seignior Lodouico

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He sir

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I cry you mercy: here is Cassio hurt by villains

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Cassio

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: How is it brother?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: My leg is cut in two

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Marry heaven forbid:
Light Gentlemen, I will bind it with my shirt

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: What is the matter ho, who is it. that cried?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Who is it. that cried

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: O my dear Cassio, O my sweet Cassio, Cassio, Cassio

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: O notable strumpet: Cassio may you suspect
Who they should be, that thus have mangled you?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I am sorry to find you thus, I have been to seek you

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Alas he faints, O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash
To bear a part in this: patience a while good Cassio:
Lend me a light; know we this face, or no?
Alas my friend, and my dear countryman:
Roderigo? no, yes sure: O heaven Roderigo

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What of Venice?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Even he sir, did you know him?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Know him? Aye

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Seignior Gratiano, I cry you gentle pardon:
These bloody accidents must excuse my manners,
That so neglected you

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I am glad to see you

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: How do you Cassio? O a chair, a chair

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Roderigo

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: He, it is he: O that is well said, a chair:
Some good man bear him carefully from hence,
I will fetch the General's Surgeon: for you mistress,
Save you your labour, he that lies slain here Cassio,
Was my dear friend, what malice was betwixt you?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: None in the world, nor do I know the man

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What, look you pale? O bear him out of the air
Stay you good Gentlewoman, look you pale mistress?
Do you perceive the gestures of her eye,
Nay, if you stir, we shall have more anon:
Behold her well I pray you, look upon her,
Do you see Gentlemen? Nay guiltiness
Will speak, though tongues were out of use

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Alas what is the matter? what is the matter husband?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Cassio has here been set on in the dark,
By Roderigo, and fellows that are scaped,
He is almost slain, and Roderigo dead

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Alas good gentleman, alas good Cassio

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: This is the fruit of whoring, pray Emillia,
Go know of Cassio, where he supped tonight:
What, do you shake at that?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: He supped at my house, but I therefore shake not

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: O did he so, I charge you go with me

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Fie, fie upon thee strumpet

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I am no strumpet, but of life as honest,
As you, that thus abuse me

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: As I: fough, fie upon thee

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Kind Gentlemen, let us go see poor Cassio dressed,
Come mistress, you must tell us another tale
Emillia, run you to the Citadel,
And tell my Lord and Lady what has happed:
Will you go on, I pray, this is the night,
That either marks me, or foredoes me quite

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul,
Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars:
It is the cause, yet I will not shed her blood,
Nor scar that whiter skin of hers, than snow,
And smooth, as monumental Alabaster;
Yet she must die, else she will betray more men,
Put out the light, and then put out the light:
If I quench thee, thou flaming minister,
I can again, thy former light restore,
Should I repent me; but once put out thine,
Thou cunning pattern of excelling nature,
I know not where is that promethian heat,
That can thy light return: when I have plucked the rose,
I cannot give it vital growth again,
It must needs wither; I will smell it on the tree,
A balmy breath, that doth almost persuade
Justice herself to break her sword once more,
Be thus, when thou art dead, and I will kill thee,
And love thee after: once more, and this the last,

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: So sweet was never so fatal: I must weep,
But they are cruel tears; this sorrow is heavenly,
It strikes when it does love: she wakes.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Who is there, Othello?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Aye, Desdemona

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Will you come to bed my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Have you prayed tonight, Desdemona?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Aye my Lord:

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: If you bethink yourself of any crime,
Unhorsing as yet to heaven and grace,
Solicit for it straight

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, what may you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Well do it, and be brief, I will walk by,
I would not kill thy unprepared spirit,
No, heaven fore-fend, I would not kill thy soul

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Talk you of killing?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Aye, I do

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Then heaven have mercy on me

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Amen, with all my heart

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: If you say so, I hope you will not kill me

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Hum

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: And yet I fear you, for you are fatal then,
When your eyes roll so: why I should fear, I know not,
Since guiltiness I know not, but yet I feel I fear

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Think on thy sins

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: They are loves I bear to you

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: And for that thou diest

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: That death is unnatural, that kills for loving,
Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip?
Some bloody passion shakes your very frame,
These are portents: but yet I hope
They do not point on me

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Peace, and be still

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: I will, so, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That handkercher which I so loved, and gave thee,
Thou gavest to Cassio

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: No, by my life and soul,
Send for the man and ask him

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Sweet soul take heed, take heed of perjury,
Thou art on thy death-bed

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Aye, but not yet to die

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Yes, presently:
Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin,
For to deny each article with oath,
Cannot remove, nor choke the strong conceit,
That I do groan withal: thou art to die

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: The Lord have mercy on me

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I say Amen

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: And have you mercy too:
I never did offend you in my life, --neuer loved Cassio,
But with such general warranty of heaven,
As I might love: I never gave him token

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: By heaven I saw my handkercher in his hand,
O perjured woman, thou dost stone thy heart,
And makest me call, what I intend to do,
A murder, which I thought a sacrifice,
I saw the handkercher

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: He found it then,
I never gave it him, send for him hither,
And let him confess a truth

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: He has confessed

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: What, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That he hath ----vds death

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: How, unlawfully?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: He will not say so

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: No, his mouth is stopped,
Honest Iago hath taken order for

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: My fear interprets then, --what is he dead?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Had all his hairs been lives,
My great revenge had stomach for them all

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Alas he is betrayed, and I undone

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O strumpet, ---weepest thou for him to my face?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: O banish me, my Lord, but kill me not

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Down strumpet

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Kill me tomorrow, let me live tonight

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Nay, if you strive

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: But half an hour, but while I say one prayer

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is too late.

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: O Lord, Lord, Lord.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, what ho, my Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What voice is this? not dead? not yet quite dead?
I that am cruel, am yet merciful,
I would not have thee linger in thy pain, --- so, so.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What ho, my Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O good my Lord, I would speak a word with you.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Yes, it is Emillia, by and by: she is dead:
It is like she comes to speak of Cassios death;
The noise was here; ha, no more moving,
Still as the grave: shall she come in? were it good?
I think she stirs again; no, what is the best?
If she come in, she will sure speak to my wife.
My wife, my wife, my wife; I have no wife;
O insupportable: O heavy hour.
Methinks it should be now a huge Eclipse
Of Sun and Moon, and that the affrighted Globe,
Should yawn at alteration.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I do beseech you I may speak with you, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I had forgot thee: O come in Emillia.
Soft, by and by; let me the Curtains draw,

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Where art thou? what is the matter with thee now?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O my good Lord, yonder is foul murders done

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What, now?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But now my Lord

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is the very error of the Moon,
She comes more near the earth, than she was wont,
And makes men mad

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Cassio my Lord has killed a young Venetian,
Called Roderigo

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Roderigo killed, and Cassio killed?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No, Cassio is not killed

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Not Cassio killed, then murder is out of tune,
And sweet revenge grows harsh

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: O falsely, falsely murdered

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O Lord, what cry is that?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That? what?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Out and alas, it is my Lady's voice,
Help, help, ho help, O Lady speak again,
Sweet Desdemona, O sweet Mistress speak

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: A guiltless death I die

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O who has done this deed?

sp.speaker: Desd.
sp.l: Nobody, I myself, farewell:
Commend me to my kind Lord, O farewell

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Why, how should she be murdered?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Alas, who knows?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: You heard her say, herself, it was not I

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: She said so, I must needs report a truth

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: She is like a liar, gone to burning Hell,
It was I that killed her

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O, the more Angel she,
And you the blacker devil

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: She turned to folly, and she was a whore

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: She was false as water

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Thou as rash as fire,
To say that she was false: O she was heavenly true

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Cassio did top her, ask thy husband else,
O I were damned beneath all depth in hell,
But that I did proceed, upon just grounds,
To this extremity, thy husband knew it all

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My husband?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Thy husband

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: That she was false to wedlock?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Aye, with Cassio: nay, had she been true,
If heaven would make me such another world,
Of one entire and perfect Chrysolite,
I would not have sold her for it

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My husband?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Aye, it was he that told me first,
An honest man he is, and hates the slime,
That sticks on filthy deeds

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My husband?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: What needs this iteration? woman, I say thy husband

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: If he say so, may his pernicious soul
Rot half a grain a day: he lies to the heart,
She was too fond of her most filthy bargain

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Do thy worst,
This deed of thine is no more worthy heaven,
Than thou wast worthy her

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Peace, you were best

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Thou hast not half the power to do me harm,
As I have to be hurt: O gull, O dolt,
As ignorant as dirt; thou hast done a deed ---
I care not for thy sword, I will make thee know,
Though I lost twenty lives : help, help, O help;
The Moore has killed my Mistress, murder, murder

div2.stage: Enter Montano, Gratiano, Iago, and others.

sp.speaker: Montanio.
sp.l: What is the matter? how now General?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O, are you come Iago? you have done well,
That men must lay their murder on your neck

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Disprove this villain, if thou beest a man;
He says thou toldest him that his wife was false,
I know thou didst not, thou art not such a villain:
Speak, for my heart is full

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I told him what I thought, and told no more,
Than what he found himself was apt and true

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But did you ever tell him she was false

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I did

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You told a lie, an odious damned lie;
Upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie:
She false with Cassio; did you say with Cassio?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: With Cassio mistress; go to, charm your tongue

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I will not charm my tongue, I am bound to speak

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: What are you mad, I charge you get you home

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen let me have leave to speak,
It is proper I obey him, but not now:
Perchance Iago, I will never go home

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Nay, lay thee down, and roar,
For thou hast killed the sweetest innocent,
That ever did lift up eye

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O she was foul:
I scarce did know you Uncle, there lies your Niece,
Whose breath indeed, these hands have newly stopped,
I know this act shows terrible and grim

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Poor Desdemona, I am glad thy father is dead,
Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief,
Shore his old thread atwain: did he live now,
This sight would make him do a desperate turn,
Yea curse his better Angel from his side,
And fall to reprobation

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: It is pitiful, but yet Iago knows,
That she with Cassio, hath the act of shame
A thousand times committed; Cassio confessed it,
And she did gratify his amorous works,
With the recognisance and pledge of love,
Which I first gave her; I saw it in his hand,
It was a handkercher; an Antique token
My father gave my mother

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O God, O heavenly God

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Zouns, hold your peace

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: It will out, it will: I hold my peace sir, no,
I will be in speaking, liberal as the air,
Let heaven, and men, and devils, let them all,
All, all cry shame against me, yet I will speak

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Be wise, and get you home

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I will not

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Fie, your sword upon a woman?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O thou dull Moore, that handkercher thou speakest on,
I found by fortune, and did give my husband:
For often with a solemn earnestness,
More than indeed belonged to such a trifle,
He begged of me to steal it

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Villainous whore

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: She gave it Cassio? no alas I found it,
And I did give it. my husband

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Filth thou liest

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: By heaven I do not, I do not Gentlemen,
O murderous Coxcomb! what should such a fool
Do with so good a woman?

div2.stage: The Moore runnes at Iago, Iago kils his wife

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Are there no stones in heaven,
But what serves for the thunder? precious villain

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: The woman falls, sure he has killed his wife

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, O lay me by my mistress's side

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: He is gone, but his wife is killed

sp.speaker: Montanio.
sp.l: It is a notorious villain, take your weapon,
Which I have here recovered from the Moore:
Come, guard the door without, let him not pass,
But kill him rather, I will after that same villain,
For it is a damned slave

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I am not valiant neither,
But every puny whipster gets my sword,
But why should honour out-live honesty?
Let it go all

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Moore, she was chaste, she loved thee cruel Moore,
So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true;
So speaking as I think, I die, I die

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I have another weapon in this chamber,
It is a sword of Spaine, the ice-brook's temper;
O here it is; Uncle I must come forth

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: If thou attempt it, it will cost thee dear,
Thou hast no weapon, and perforce must suffer

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Look in upon me then, and speak to me,
Or naked as I am, I will assault thee

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Behold, I have a weapon,
A better never did itself sustain
Upon a Soldier's, thigh: I have seen the day,
That with this little arm, and this good sword,
I have made my way through more impediments,
Than twenty times you stop: but O vain boast,
Who can control his Fate? it is not so now,
Pale as thy smock, when we shall meet at count,
This look of thine, will hurl my soul from heaven,
And fiends will snatch at it: cold, cold, my girl,
Even like thy chastity; O cursed slave:
Whip me you Devils,
From the possession of this heavenly sight,
Blow me about in winds, roast me in sulphur,
Wash me in steep down gulfs of liquid fire:
O Desdemona, Desdemoua, dead, O, o, o

div2.stage: Enter Lodouico, Montano, Iago, and Officers, Cassio in a Chaire.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Where is this rash and most infortunate man

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: That is he that was Othello, here I am

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Where is this Viper, bring the villain forth

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I look down towards his feet, but that is a fable
If thou beest a devil, I cannot kill thee

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Wring his sword from him

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: I bleed sir, but not killed

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I am not sorry neither, I would have thee live,
For in my sense it is happiness to die

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O thou Othello, that wert once so good,
Fallen in the practise of a damned slave,
What should be said to thee?

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Why anything,
An honourable murderer if you will:
For naught did I in hate, but all in honour

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This wretch hath part confessed his villainy:
Did you and he consent in Cassio's death?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Dear General, I did never give you cause

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I do believe it, and I ask you pardon,
Will you pray, demand that demi-devil,
Why he hath thus ensnared my soul and body?

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Demand me nothing, what you know you know,
From this time forth I never will speak word

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What not to pray?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Torments will ope your lips

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Well, thou dost best

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sir, you shall understand what hath befallen,
Which, as I think you know not: here is a letter,
Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo;
And here another; the one of them imports
The death of Cassio; to be undertook ---by Roderigo

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O villain

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Most heathenish, and most gross

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now here is another discontented paper,
Found in his pocket too, and this it seems,
Roderigo meant to have sent this damned villain,
But that belike, Iago, in the nick
Came in, and satisfied him

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O the pernicious caitiff!
How came you Cassio by a handkercher,
That was my wife's?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I found it in my chamber,
And he himself confessed it even now,
That there he dropped it, for a special purpose;
Which wrought to his desire

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: O fool, fool, fool

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: There is besides in Roderigoes letter
How he upbraids Iago, that he made him,
Brave me upon the watch, whereon it came,
That I was cast; and even but now he spake,
After long seeming dead, Iago hurt him,
Iago set him on

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You must forsake this room, and go with us,
Your power and your command is taken off,
And Cassio rules in Cypres: for this slave,
If there be any cunning cruelty,
That can torment him much, and hold him long,
It shall be his: you shall close prisoner rest,
Till that the nature of your fault be known
To the Venetian State; come, bring him away

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: Soft you, a word or two,
I have done the State some service, and they know it;
No more of that: I pray you in your letters,
When you shall these unlucky deeds relate,
Speak of them as they are; nothing extenuate,
Nor set down aught in malice, then must you speak,
Of one that loved not wisely, but too well:
Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought,
Perplexed in the extreme; of one whose hand,
Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away,
Richer than all his Tribe: of one whose subdued eyes,
Albeit unused to the melting mood,
Drops tears as fast as the Arabian trees,
Their medicinal gum; set you down this,
And say besides, that in Aleppo once,
Where a Malignant and a Turbaned Turk,
Beat a Venetian, and traduced the State;
I took by the throat the circumcised dog,
And smote him thus

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O bloody period

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: All that is spoke is marred

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.l: I kissed thee ere I killed thee, no way but this,
Killing myself, to die upon a kiss

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon,
For he was great of heart

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O Spartan dog,
More fell than anguish, hunger, or the Sea,
Look on the tragic lodging of this bed:
This is thy work, the object poisons sight,
Let it be hid: Gratiano, keep the house,
And seize upon the fortunes of the Moore:
For they succeed to you, to you Lord Governor,
Remains the censure of this hellish villain,
The time, the place, the torture: O enforce it,
Myself will straight aboard, and to the State,
This heavy act with heavy heart relate
